This game is quietly one of the best FPS of the last decade. It packs so much content and value into a game that is regularly on sale for 5 bucks. Considering what you can get it for I believe it is a must own for anyone who enjoys FPS. There is something for everyone with amazing Pilot combat, modifiable Titans with 6 different classes, PvE mode, a great campaign, and different builds and so much cosmetics to grind. You can bend bullets with gravity stars people. I holds up to the hype and besides the lack of a ping system it hasn't shown its age.
I love Titanfall, they should make a 3rd.
just buy the game

First off Titanfall 2 on PC runs pretty easily on almost anything to a low end desktop or a low end laptop. Probably can run on some AMD integrated APU's as long as they are toward the higher end of APU's chart. I even tested it on my Acer ultra book with a six core AMD CPU and RTX 3050 at 40W and I was getting north of 120fps at 1080p high settings (just FYI game is cap at 144FPS on PC / Xbox Series consoles 120FPS with FPS boost). VRAM for me was the limiting factor on my ultra book. The game looks great, I personnel love the source engine and I had no issues regardless of what system I ran it on. Being the PC version needs EA's own launcher to run as well is a drawback for me. If I'm buying on Steam that should be good enough. Titanfall is my favorite shooter it's so fast and smooth and rewarding to play. The community size seem to be pretty good on PC I've observed around 3,000 players and I play off peak times. Single player story mode is great if a little short. The only two online modes I was able to find games in reliably were attrition (PVP with titans) and frontier defense (4 player PVE).  

I believe a lot of new players will be turned off by the skill gap that will be vary obvious from the start. All Titanfall games are very fast paced with split second reactions being key. The game seem to have little to no skill based matchmaking. As I was new I was put into matches with top tier players of god like skills. Maybe is because the player base is kind of small but most all the matches I've played were very lopsided, your either going to win by a landslide or lose by a landslide. I did however have a few good close matches but I can count them on one hand so not many. If you stick with it and unlock equipment as you level you will improve your skills. It dose support controller but I would recommend keyboard and mouse if you want to be competitive on the PC version. K&M is how I play it. 

Now the reason I feel I can't recommend the PC version of Titanfall 2, the aimbots and hackers in the online. I don't think EA monitors this game or ever did. It's very obvious if you look in the lobbies just highlight a players name that looks out of place like they rolled there face on their keyboard to create there name and then look at there stats. The time played - how many matches they have played - how many games they have won - how many kills they have - how much they are worth - what level they are at will not add up in any persons mind. If that's not clear enough I've ran into hackers and aimbot in game more times then I would like to admit and even in Frontier defense and that blows my mind.  In Frontier defense you can level weapons but not titans you use in PVP so I guess that would be one reason why to cheat in a PVE mode? 

Another issue with PC is you may not be able to connect to Respawns servers if your on a newer computer. This requires you to change a setting in Windows environmental settings to get it to work. I've also observed that more players on PC use broken builds/load-outs that are known to be over powered or broken from launch. I guess if you want to make the game easy in PVP just use a over powered build, I'm not sure why this is so prominent on PC but it stands out. it is part of the game so it's not cheating it is what it is and the developer never changed anything for the most part regarding weapon balancing. 

I guess if I never spent time on the console versions of this game maybe these issues wouldn't be that big of a deal. But the fact is I have and on Console I have a ton of time played on the game and I haven't run into hackers / aimbots. The console player base don't seem to utilize the over powered load-outs nearly as much as players do on PC so take that for what it's worth. Online matches seem to be way more competitive on console, the matches are much closer with less blowouts. It's still and amazing game on PC, good story and if not for the flaws of online cheating would be a solid recommendation but for me I'll be spending more of my titanfall time on console as that experience is way more enjoyable and not filled with as may issues. 

On a side note: if your looking for the original titanfall game the only way to play it now is on xbox as EA messed up the pc version and it's no longer playable. You either need to own it digitally already as EA has pulled it off the xbox store or get the game disc. The original Titanfall on xbox still has a small but solid player base at peak play times on weekends but is not nearly as big as Titanfall 2. Love Titanfall 1 & 2

One of the best non-standard FPS games ever made. The c ampaign story goes hard like nothing else, it's fun, it's thrilling, it's sad, it's funny... The multiplayer is awesome, with gamemodes for everyone and their mom - there's even PVE! And of course, the movement in this game is something one will not have perfected after 1000 hours. Wallrunning, double jump, grappling hook, invisibility... It has it all! And then of course the aspect that gave this franchise it's name - the titans. Man, Titan gameplay is amazing, and no other game manages to capture or replicate that. Theres sniper titans, melee titans with an electrocuted sweord, fire titans, minigun titans, whatever you want... This game came out 8 years ago, and it's still such a banger! You should definetely play it, it will be money well spent.

I honestly cant understand why this game is so praised. The campaign, from a story perspective is just a filler and its mediocre at best. The level design and the platforming elements are nice but that's about it. The multiplayer has no skill based matchmaking system so its not newbie friendly at all. The game has a small community and most matches you will be fighting against veteran players. They know the maps by heart, they have all the weapon and titan upgrades. The wall running and the other mechanics are interesting.

Since the game doesn't have any anti cheat many people use soft aim assists or chronus zen and wall hacks. There is even a cheat that allows you to get your titan in the first minute of the game or another that makes it so you don't lose all your life when others hit you. Basically shots aren't registered. Sometimes the servers go wonky from 50ms ping to 300ms, game starts to look choppy and you die not knowing what or how it hit you and the kill cam shows something entirely different than what you saw on the screen previous to your demise :). Also because of the servers there are hit registration issues, where your shots arent detected or you sometimes die behind a wall.
Also the community is very toxic. People fill the chat with slurs depending on what titan, weapon or boost you pick. Sometimes you get in balanced lobbies and then its fun but its rare and its more of a coin flip.

I got the game on sale for 4 euros. Sadly, i'd say that is exactly what its worth.

A lot like [i]Portal[/i], [i]Titanfall 2[/i]'s campaign is very short, but that's because there's absolutely no fluff—every moment of it is fun and engaging to play, with new mechanics and abilities constantly being introduced to shake things up. The core gameplay is balanced perfectly between the lightning fast and smooth movement on foot, and the slow, hulking, powerful feeling of controlling a titan. There are few other shooters that make you feel like a badass as much as this game does. Story-wise, it's not going to blow you away or anything, but it works perfectly for what it needs to be, with the development of the central characters' relationship being surprisingly interesting and emotional at times.

Basically everything good about the campaign's gameplay also applies to the multiplayer and frontier defense gamemode, it's all super fast-paced and incredibly fun. Of all the more modern FPS games in the vein of [i]Call of Duty[/i] or [i]Battlefield[/i], this one clearly stands head and shoulders above the rest.

Great game! The fast pace, wall running and sliding is what sold me to purchase this. Jumping straight into the online matches just after finishing basic training lead to many of my deaths lol and only killing a player or two but I had a lot of fun! Now 87hrs later, after having many rounds and finding out the hard way that the grunts/AI forces are not all push overs (may or may not have died so many times to them...) and figuring out what loadout works best for me, it is one of my favorite FPS games to play.
 
One of the only things that gets me though, is the enemy team's grunts having the same voice/lines as your ally grunts. I think it would of been better for them to sound a bit different imo. Although, I'd still give it a 10/10 for the great action.

You know that feeling when you fall in love?

Well this isn't it because games are virtual goods so it's kind of hard for one to fall in love like in a physical sense however that does not mean that one can not appreciate something that isn't real and in that sense, as other reviews and a lot of them can contest at this moment in time (overwhelmingly positive), a lot of people feel this way about this particular game.

For one I was a fan of Star Wars: Republic Commando, a tactical shooter that reminds me of this game and even though this particular game feels more arcadey that does not take away from its core.

What I see when I look at the core, without staring is that the game looks beautiful and that it plays really nicely. This combination is already something that would engage me with a product like this and on top of that I really am interested that is to say: intrigued by the story. I already kind of am a fan of technology and the potential future it holds, albeit depicted in a warring sense in this game but still it does not take away from the wonder of it all. I think the developers have been meticulous in designing and building this game and it shows.

I do like it a lot. I have been postponing the notion to buy it for a long time and now that I have I am satisfied with how the game plays and how it looks and again its story. It is not something I would necessarily go out of my way and to buy again let's say at full price because it's a type of game that except the story and the action found contained within the story I do not necessarily like in terms of let's say the skill aspect where in a PvP; Player versus Player environment I am kind of not interested in competing but with emphasis on competition and the fact to really get some skills you have to learn them first which isn't a huge problem the issue with me is that to get good at a game let's say in an online environment one has to develop like let's say create and sharpen and maintain those skills in which sense I'd rather play 100 games than just simply get really good at one.  Even though this has happened in the past, that I've dedicated myself to one particular game for a long period of time and had even gotten good at it, let's say that age and slowly but surely growing older does not help in this regard of like being able to achieve what once was possible even though I do not speak for everyone when I say this but somewhere in between there lies a truth.

A truth that goes something along the lines of;
I'd rather have thick plot armor than a poor experience online, by which I do not hint at my own skills and the willingness to use them but rather I'd fight in a Co-Op with my brothers against the big bad (that's like powered by an AI of sorts or just a CPU) rather than fighting against them. Against Us. Also fact that sometimes cheaters can ruin the fun (not commenting on Titanfall multiplayer which I know or just assume that a lot of people are a fan of but rather: speaking in general terms) is something I am not so much willing to deal with too much "these days" or since they kind of swarmed the online games, but that's something for another time...

Anyway, I am and still will remain more of a fan of tactical first or even third person shooters and most of all: immersive sims but I think that a few aspects of those things in this game, despite its fast pace can be somewhat found and this is why I do like the game contextually, thematically and as well aesthetically and I would recommend it to other players to jump into it and play at least the single player component because it is pleasing and fun.

Dedicated to (the game and) memories and shared experiences.
Kind regards BT-7274

Single player was fun, I figure there's a type of person who likes the multiplayer but it's not me. 

Don't get me wrong the gameplay is fantastic, but there's just something off with it. The ttk is very low but respawns are very fast so it balances out a bit. Maps feel a bit too funneled with how you spawn in basically the same area you died 4/5 times. Some weapons/titans feel like they do a million damage to everything while others seem to just be wet cardboard sticks. But all of those are just nitpicks.

The main reason for me putting down this game and not trying to get better at it is that the game doesn't tell me if I did good or not. Even games like Squad that are mil-sims without scoreboards still tell me how many times I died at the end of the match. Titanfall 2 does not do that, instead it tells you how many pilots and npcs you killed and you have to infer how many times you died based on that relation to other people. But as a gamer, I understand that I could have 10,000 kills but if I died 1,000,000 times getting them it wasn't worth it. How am I, as a person who enjoys competition in my multiplayer competitive games, expected to improve on myself when all you give me is a kill count? The human mind is notoriously faulty, how do you expect me to remember and reflect on every death I had in a game centered around being even faster paced then CoD? It's quite frankly ridiculous in this era of esports launching with every popular game to not at least acknowledge what is typically the most dedicated type of player. This lack of foresight is, in my opinion, the primary reason this game is not more popular. Why would I wan't to play a first-person shooter where I'm not even rewarded for doing well and we all get participation trophies?

This game is lackluster in general, but it's already dead and typically like 5 bucks on sale so go ahead and buy it.

ALSO, the game is horrendously monetized I'm pretty sure I saw multiple skins being sold for $5 (the price of the game) but to be fair I don't think there were any pay to win mechanics.

Also, why would you add severe bullet travel time to the sniper in a game where everyone never stops moving at 100000 miles an hour and in order to use it you have to stop moving in which case you almost always immediately die.

Some of these dev decisions are just weird.
If you love Apex Legends, this is must buy! You won't regret it ;)

Murdered by EA when they squeezed it between battlefield 1 and cod and declared a flop, it's he most overlooked and underrated fps game of all times. And that's a damn shame, because it has:
* a wonderful 5h-ish singleplayer campaign with feels
* active multiplayer PvP and PvE
* insane fluid movement
* great feeling weapons
* TITANS, the gigantic mechs Apex Legends (which is in titanfall's universe) doesn't have, with additional ultimate mechanic
* weapon and titan customization offering diverse gameplay styles
Get it on sale - it goes on sale with every Steam sale, but even at full price it's worth it. Respawn fixed the hacker/ddos problem which was plaguing titanfall 2 for years, making the game playable again around Fall 2023. The game was so good that even when the original client was suffering, people made Northstar client to be able to play - this says something about how good the game is that even 3rd party solutions were made to keep it alive.
A big thumbs up, it's worth for the singleplayer campaign alone, which is one of the better stories told in fps games. But try multiplayer too, if you like fast paced combat and cutthroat no hands holding PvP, you won't be dissapointed. You can trap enemy pilots in a gravity grenade and then shoot them, you can step on them or meelee them with your titan, you can perform executions on titans and pilots or you can rodeo a pesky titan and steal its battery or throw a grenade into its hatch, the weapons range from hitscan to relatively slow moving balls of hate. There's lot to uncover and explore wrt mechanic, and campaign has a replayability value in the form of hidden collectibles, and speedrun community which gatered around this game (search YT for "titanfall speedrun" but AFTER you do the singleplayer campaign, because spoilers). I love this game and I have over 300hrs in it now on Origin/EAApp, but recently I transferred over to steam to be able to change game language. EA being EA region-locked the game language to PL/RU where I live and when I made a bad decision to give them more money and purchase deluxe edition (some weapon and titan skins) it re-locked itself (I had international key before). Luckily, steam purchase solved that and now I have intl. version with Polish included. Thanks GabeN ♥

Incredible game, even more amazing when I realized that this was made in 2016. The pilot/mech dynamic is my favorite aspect. As a pilot you are incredibly nimble and can traverse terrain with ease. As a mech you become a war machine with massive presence and an immense firepower to unleash against your targets.
The wall running was a bit tricky to get used to at first, but playing the campaign really helped me understand the wall jump. My main gripe with this game is the lack of customization, but I understand that this is an older game and Respawn is focusing on Apex. I do wish they would put more love back into this franchise, I would certainly buy Titanfall 3 if it ever came out.
Overall wonderful game. Absolutely recommend. Multiplayer lobbies are still alive and well with many game modes. Since picking up this game a few weeks ago que times have been about 2 minutes or so. 
Cmon pilot, don't just standby, call in your titan and join us on the frontier. You won't regret it. Trust me.

While Titanfall 1 is a masterpiece, Titanfall 2 is mediocre.
Campaign with its gimmicks was a nice addition compared to the first game, however the game was heavily downgraded compared to original by getting rid of core design ideas such as multiplayer campaign, cutscenes, soundtrack, grounded design, titan rodeo, grunts cinematic presence on a level with various voice lines, actions and animations as well as first person executions and animations that really immersed you in the first title. While Titanfall 2 should have been excelled at fixing what Titanfall 1 had issues with, it instead took major step back while adding ever more modern gimmicks such as grappling hook.
I cannot in clear conscience recommend this game, just play Titanfall 1. Will make it positive just out of respect for Titanfall 1

Titanfall 2 is an absolute masterpiece of a game that seamlessly blends fast-paced action with compelling storytelling. From exhilarating titan battles to adrenaline-fueled pilot maneuvers, every moment is filled with excitement. The level design is top-notch, offering a perfect balance of verticality and strategic options. Additionally, the multiplayer experience is incredibly immersive, with diverse maps and dynamic gameplay mechanics. With its stunning visuals and addictive gameplay, Titanfall 2 is a must-play for any action gaming enthusiast.

Its titanfall, if you haven't heard/played it by now, I seriously question your presence on the internet. Truly one of my favorite games of all time. I wouldn't say the story is the craziest, multiple award winning type but it is enjoyable and engaging enough to where you care about whats going on and continue playing to see what happens next. Personally I liked the story a lot. Where this game shines is in its mechanics. My god is it so much fun, I mean everything is perfect. The combat, movement, pacing, mechanics, weapons just everything is so damn smooth and very much a blast to experience. Its visually stunning and the world is nicely put together. For sure one of the most fun times I have have had while playing a game. They really perfected the mechanics in this game and no other game has been able to replicate it. Absolutely wonderful game. Even if you don't like shooter games, the campaign is still worth experiencing. The voice acting is spectacular and really makes you CARE about the characters, something many other games fall short of reaching, the gameplay is just as good, with many guns, abilities, etc., that add both enjoyment and variety to the game. Definitely worth the very cheap pricepoint(not to mention that it often goes on sale for $3.). Despite the praise, however, I do have some problems, mainly the fact that Titanfall as a whole has been pretty much abandoned by EA and Respawn in favor of Apex Legends, though I hear of rumors of a third game? Perhaps. The visuals do get a little boring at some points, and there are several parts that aren't as realistic as I'd like(looking at you, radiation room that you "can't stay in for too long" that you can actually stay in for forever in The Beacon... also the part where BT grabs you in the SAME LEVEL after falling from at LEAST 50 meters up, MORE than enough to kill a person), but overall, those experiences barely drag down the better parts of the game. I give Titanfall 2 a very solid 9/10. Buy this game now.

[b]EDIT:[/b]


Online appears to be working again. 



[b]PRE-EDIT:[/b]

Review before DDOS --->

I initially bought this because I like the idea of mech suit sci-fi games. The multiplayer is probably one of the more interesting experiences you will have in an FPS game. Hopefully I will come back to this review with more detail when I have time and think of new things to say. Frankly, I'd just rather play more Titanfall 2 than write this review, but these things need to be said. This game is criminally underrated, but has a strong and growing fanbase as recently as January 2021.



[b]Story mode[/b] -  [9/10]

Very original for a video game about mech suits. Beautiful story. Smooth game mechanics. Variety of challenges, despite linearity. Multiple difficulty settings for both die hards and beginners. Objectives are clear, but not spoonfed to you (except at the very beginning with the tutorial). The whole game feels fresh and exciting throughout, even on multiple replays (hard to even identify a specific gameplay loop for single player mode, which is a good thing). 


[b]Multiplayer[/b] - [8/10]  SEE EDIT --> I've since changed the rating to [9/10]

Great, but sometimes hard to find games since it isn't the most recent game around. Works faster if you join a network then invite players from that network to join your party. If you queue up 1 or 2 game modes and disable the rest, it will find matches faster (especially Attrition mode).

EDIT: VERY AWESOME once you find people to play with and also start to take advantage of the 'Invite Network' function, which results in faster matches and less waiting. On the whole, very friendly community. There are however a few bad apples who are toxic. My favorite way to play is with friends using mics on Discord (although there is in-game push-to-talk in TF2). Changing my rating for multiplayer from [8/10] to [9/10]. 



[b]Graphics/Software/Hardware[/b] - [9.5/10]

Still looks current in 2020, which is really saying something considering it came out in 2016. Beautiful game, great frame rates, and wonderful graphics. 

Game does crash occasionally and can be occasionally finicky with the window settings, however it still runs very well. 

I run the game at a VERY steady 75 FPS on a 75 Hz monitor with a NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650 (definitely not a top tier graphics card) at max graphic settings. Before, I was running it with 120 FPS (with only occasional frame drops) on a 60 Hz monitor, but it got harder to do once I started playing online (even with some overclocking). A decent internet connection speed (whatever this means to you) is definitely recommended for online play. 



[b]Replay value[/b] - [8.5/10]

Story mode is very linear; however if you enjoy the multiplayer, you can get hours and hours out of this game. I didn't even really play FPS games online before this and I've managed to put in over 200 hours now. 


[b]Weapons/loadouts[/b] - [9/10]

So many unique and functional weapons for a variety of styles of play. It's great. I like to use 
cloak, EPG, MGL, and Legion Titan (Predator cannon, which is essentially a gatling-style minigun/rotary machine gun). So many different combinations to fit your style of play. 




[b]OVERALL RATING[/b] - 90% - A - [45/50]

[b] TL;DR = Get it NOW while it's on sale <£5 just for the campaign. No regrets. [/b]

I have mixed feelings with this one but can't deny that the campaign was short but sweet and pretty awesome - and for £2.49 (what I paid for it), I definitely got my money's worth. 

I'm just disappointed that the campaign was so short and one sided. You only get to play as the Militia (rebel scum) /yawn. Now if there had to been another 6 hour campaign included where you play as the IMC then it'd be a 10/10 (like the first Titanfall). 

It seems most of the dev time/effort went into the multiplayer and cash shop (paid skins, microtransactions). 

There is also a co-op [i] defence [/i] mode but I haven't tested that or the multiplayer yet. I fear I'll drown in sweat and become lost in a jungle of neckbeard - judging by some of the negative reviews, I'm right in thinking that. 

I already can tell it's not going to be as good as TF1's multiplayer (or the game in general) - I prefer it's simplicity. Here there's funky weapon/armour/titan skins and microtransactions and just too much going on (that's just from looking at the loadouts). I haven't seen any pink Titan skins at least. There's quite a few game modes though which is cool like capture the flag or a mode where it's just pilots vs pilots (no Titans) or one where everyone starts in a Titan - at least there's options and it seems easy enough to choose what you want to participate in.

Also a pet peeve - it's no longer simple IMC vs Militia. Dumb is what it is.

But as for the single player campaign... 

The combat is fast paced and satisfying as are the weapons - it's fluid and at least for me feels natural. It didn't take long to get into the swing of things, although I did play many, many hours of the first Titanfall back in the day so maybe some of it's from memory. 

There's a nice balance between pilot (on-foot) and Titan gameplay and 
the interaction/dialogue/relationship between them is wholesome. 

There is at least one returning character "Blisk" who was basically your commander during the IMC campaign in the first Titanfall and there are small references to Demeter which I thought was cool. 

There's a handful of boss fights throughout the game and each one is unique.

There's some annoying enemies that can one shot you and can I just say, fuck those fucking ticks, man.

A decent amount of variety in all areas of the game. 

Overall, I enjoyed it enough to play it all in one sitting and if I can squeeze some entertainment out of the online portion then well, value for money +1000%. If not, I still got my money's worth. 

Ultimately though, I feel more comfortable Not Recommending it for some of
the reason above... Plus, it's EA we're talking about. Nothing good comes from that.
There's microtransactions and only a 6-hr campaign because most dev time went into
making weapon skins. EA's fault most likely. = 🖕It's obvious that most of the effort 
was put into the online making skins and microtransactions. If that effort had been put 
to the single player, we could've got another 6 hour campaign. Perhaps one for us IMC 
bros. But greed always wins. Think about that. Overwhelmingly (positive) overrated 
more like. 

Balance must be restored so this is me doing my part by Not Recommending this.

UPDATE: The Frontier Defence co-op mode is pretty fun.

EVERYTHING IN THIS GAME IS A MASTER PIECE

Before you buy: You still need a crappy Origin account to play this game and 'mini' Origin launcher still secretly runs in the background but don't let that discourage you into playing one the greatest single/multiplayer FPS game out there.

Single player campaign: Rare to see a good FPS campaign these days, it's basically a 6 hour tutorial combined with excellent storytelling/lore. Most players will appreciate the slow learning curve and will have more confidence into playing against other real players online with their new set of parkour and titan handling skills. 

Multiplayer: Only played a few games but I know it’s going to be hectic, this game was released a while ago so that means evil EA didn’t ruin it with loot boxes or nasty micro transactions to hinder player progress like their other games…
One thing I like is that the game still rewards you when you lose so players could still have fun and progress even if you keep getting destroyed.

Buy this game if you love:
-Bad ass looking titans
-A single player experience you will never forget  
-Fun Futuristic weapons and gadgets
-Free movement in the battlefield or smooth parkour systems
-Customisation of everything you could think off by just playing the game.

I can fully recommend a purchase of this game. 
The campaign took me around 6 hours to complete. The story, when boiled down, is kind of generic with its plot themes, but the immersive and vibrant world of Titanfall really helps to make it feel unique.
The multiplayer is where Titanfall's movement and combat set it apart from other games. The movement is sublime, and the combat feels great. Unfortunately, there are a small list of gripes I have with the multiplayer. I don't find the progression system to be that good, especially when talking about primary weapons. All weapons, to my knowledge, get the same unlocks and in the same order. I wish there was more variety when it came to that. Also, as fun as the multiplayer is, it gets repetitive very quickly if you don't switch up gamemodes. It seems like everybody plays Attrition all day. My final gripe is that everyone has a bright red outline over their character to improve visibility during the fast paced and hectic action. Yeah, it makes target acquisition easy, but it lowers the skill ceiling.
Other than that the game is great.

Titanfall 2 is one of the best FPS games ever. I mean it. Its campaign has some of the best writing, voice acting and gameplay I have ever seen!

I'll just be covering the Campaign for this review by the way. You play as SRS Rifleman Jack Cooper, who is in training to become a Pilot, a super soldier with all the best qualities, including a Titan - A 25 foot tall heap of metal with state of the art weaponry and AI. When things go awry with your Mentor, Captain Tai Lastimosa, your job is to pick up the mantle of Pilot and save the world. With your Titan, BT-7274, you make your way through battlefields and different lands, trying to disable a weapon of mass destruction. 

I absolutely adore Titanfall 2. There aren't a lot of games that genuinely make me feel flurries of sadness, anger and happiness quite like this game. If you haven't gotten this game, please, please do pick it up. You won't regret it.

this game is basically perfect. if you want a fast paced run and gun game, this is it. the multiplayer servers recently got completely fixed, so you don't have to install a mod anymore to play it. the campaign is a MASTERPIECE. the story isn't much to look at, its just there for context. but the GAME PLAY is phenominal. this game isn't made by just the mech game play or just the pilot game play. its made by how they SEAMLESSLY blend together to make the smoothest game you will ever experience. the controls are intuitive, the movement perfect, and the mechs are a total blast. the game isn't perfect. there is a very steep learning curve depending the servers you join. but with the new easy access multiplayer, there is a LOT more new players. so its easier than ever to learn. this game isn't perfect, but its the closest i think we'll get for a while. if you like fast paced movement, very good feeling guns, and large robots with missiles, then this game is for you. i hope if you read this review, it convinces you to buy this game. it is worth the price, especially when its on sale. i would pay $30 for the campaign ALONE. jut buy the game and try it out. if you don't like it, refund it. its usually around $20, just get it.

It's been a while since I've enjoyed a new clean, simple, single-player FPS campaign.  It's a bit nostalgic.

Titanfall 2 is fast-paced FPS where you parkour around so that you don't get shot.  Both you and the soldiers you face are squishy and heavily armed.  But you're faster!

The titan-fighting is also cool, with some dodging - but the titans are a little less quick in that respect.  But they make up for it in cool weapons and abilities.

The story is a bit cheesy, but I enjoyed the arc of friendship between pilot and titan.
The levels are high quality and keep it fresh with unique mechanics.

Titanfall 2 is a masterpiece.

Titanfall 2 is my favorite game of all time, and holds up really, really well, even 7 years after its first release in 2016, and can still go toe-to-toe with the most modern titles in my opinion. For a game published by EA, there is a massive lack of micro transactions, with the only real ones being the Monarch's Reign DLC (which, comes with the Ultimate Edition, which is the only one you can buy now), and some skins in the shop, and prime titans, which are very out of the way and unobtrusive. Titanfall 2 was abandoned for a little while, however it seems that Respawn is coming back to it, and is even teasing a 3rd installment, which would most likely be revealed at The Game Awards. The multiplayer is amazing, there are still thousands of people playing, and the community, which is often overlooked in many games, is absolutely amazing. The campaign is probably one of the best ones to come out in recent memory. While short, it is still one of the most fun experiences I have had in a game. 

TL;DR, Titanfall 2's community, campaign, and multiplayer are all awesome. Now go play it.

I only played the single player campaign and truly enjoyed the action and story. It's not too complicated per-se, but there's enough tactics to be had with the pilot and titan interaction. Story is short, took me 7 hours (with the occasional death), and I'm sure many can finish it in 5 hours or even less. But if you're not looking for something that requires a ton of investment and like to play shorter single-player shooters such as CoD for their story and then you put the game aside (and don't bother with multi-player), then it's worth getting especially if on sale (which I heard sometimes approached about five bucks or so). It's quite pretty too, and I had no technical difficulties. Editing the config file even allowed my dual 4K resolution to work at 7680x2160.

Unfortunately it comes with the EA launcher which I uninstalled immediately after finishing, and uninstalling the game. Almost willing to give it a thumbs down because of that.

An absolute masterpiece. If you like first-person shooters even the slightest bit, it's your duty to try this thing out. The balance of pilot / titan combat is just perfect: the fast, parkour-like freedom of movement of the fragile pilots carrying relatively weak weapons contrasts with large, powerful, but slower and less manoeuvrable robots with specialised weapon loadouts.

Not only do you get the contrast between the two modes within the same game, you get a wildly different experience depending on which combinations of pilot and titan loadout you use. Although you're likely to settle on your favourite titans and pilot loadouts, one of the best features of this game is that you can have tons of fun just trying something different out for a game or two. Some of the most fun games I've played have been the ones where I'm the lowest-scoring member of the losing team.

The single-player campaign is excellent too, a combination of excellent story-telling and tutorial for the main game mechanics you'll need in multiplayer. I only regret not having tried Titanfall 2 out earlier - I discovered it in September 2023 when it was on sale and I've literally played no other game since. 10/10, the best video game I've ever played.

Not a perfect game, a lot of the maps are garbage and gamemodes featuring both Titans and Pilots are pretty unbalanced- actually, this game has a pretty big problem regarding balance. For both Titans and Pilot weapons, there is a clear choice that is just better in almost every situation, leaving the variety and fun of the game up to however you decide to play. Luckily, most players tend to play the more enjoyable Titans and pick the less OP weapons, so this unbalance in the game isn't always a problem that you will feel.
  
The most fun in this game comes from its community content on the community run Northstar servers, so if you buy this game be sure to go check those out here: [url=https://northstar.tf/] https://northstar.tf/ [/url]   
  
Besides the multiplayer, the campaign is extremely well made, and if you enjoy things like speedrunning, it is an absolute treat.


  This review doesn't go into detail because I dont feel like writing that much, but if you like fps games that ask you to do more than just walk forward and point directly at an enemy to kill them, then Titanfall 2 will likely end up as a favorite.

Titanfall 2 and especially Titanfall 1 are by far the best shooters ever made, nothing comes close and i have played everything from Quake to Apex.
It breaks my heart to see people wanting "innovation" and "fun gameplay", but abandon games the second they notice they can't get some dopamine rush from battle passes and/or loot boxes.

The adrenaline rush i get from working together with my buddies, chaining flags, teaming Titans, or just escaping when a match was lost beats any curated psychological bling bling slot machine any day.
The sad thing is that people do not know whats fun anymore. They go on social media, TikTok, mindlessly consume, waiting for that artificial gratitude. Incredible game.  Storyline is a 5/5.  Core game mechanics feel amazing.  Visuals still hold up almost a decade later. 
But the multiplayer is so incredibly frustrating sometimes.

When its good, its so incredibly addicting.  I've burned entire days away playing this game, both singleplayer and multiplayer.  The rush of taking down a titan, obliterating armies of ai grunts, or pulling off crazy acrobatics to kill an enemy pilot that clearly had the drop on you.  As much as Blisk might try to drill into your head that you shouldn't try to be a hero, you certainly feel like one or at the very least a badass.

But lately I've noticed a change, which unfortunately follows right on the tails of the community becoming revived.  

Approximately 10% of my shots simply do not connect when they should have.  This is pretty much inconsequential when running smgs or anything that goes brr and sprays pilots to death.  However, if you find yourself in a long term relationship with a G2 or any other weapon that requires a few extra clicks its painfully apparent.  I've gotten into melee fights where it seems as though we kicked at the same but my opponent ends up unscathed.  I would go and watch the kill cam and its revealed that i never kicked at all.  I check my ping and its sitting pretty at 50-60 ms.

Spawn killing is an inherent core multiplayer experience.  Once you have the enemy on their heels, you can just keep rotating around the map in your titan gang beating the snot out of pilots who spawned seconds earlier. 

There are chat spam bots who read like if you fed chatgpt nothing but mw2 lobby transcriptions.  They're "harmless" as one veteran pointed out, but annoying nonetheless. 

Overall, I wish there was a point system for steam store, because its not a bad game in the slightest.  I would give it a 7/10 but wouldn't necessarily recommend it for anyone who isn't already playing.

Well, it's taken years to get around to playing this game. I've always been a huge Halo fan and I ignored pretty much everything else for a long time. I was wrong. The campaign has been one of the most entertaining, if short-lived, experiences I've ever had in a shooter. I'm echoing what others have said before me, but the movement and gunplay are second to none. I went back to Halo and felt like I was wading through treacle. 

You're not going to get the same experience anywhere else. This is not COD, BF, PUBG or Apex. This is you, your jump pack and BT-7274 trying your damnedest to uphold the mission.

[h1] Recommended: Yes[/h1]
[b] Rating: 9.0/10.0[/b]

Summary: I think Titanfall ® 2 is a good game, probably legitimately a great game, but was released in Q3 2016 when it competed with other good games at the time like Call Of Duty. It's a game where you take the role of cooper, a pilot of arobot warrior called Titan. I did not play the first in the series, by the way. I do not remember it being a huge hit. Rumors say it was a multiplayer focused game. But I experienced Titanfall 2 to be a polished game with a solid single player campaign. It was smooth, and featured mechanics rarely seen in other games, like switching between humans and robots, as well as acrobatics and time travel mechanics combined, which makes for a refreshing change. It seems to have a solid multiplayer base, but I have not tried it. Will there be a Titanfall 3? It deserves it.

 

[b] Pros: [/b]
[list]
[*] Acrobatics are fun in that there's wall running, but what makes this a one-of-a-kind experience is when you combine it with time travel.
[*] Fights against other Titans especially are epic, and feels like a Call of Duty in the Titanfall world. 
[*] Interesting storyline, where one might care enough once you get past the more boring and normal parts of the first 1 hour or so.
[*] There is a wide variety of weapons and Titan upgrades which looks like class changes. 
[*] Good list of bosses with interesting characters.
[*] A bit of a touching story, not sure why but it seems more engaging than most others.
[*] This game doesn't need a wiki. It's pretty much self explanatory unless you want to collect items. The simplicity is good when you are looking for simple, fast action games. 
[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] First hour or so looks mundane, like a normal shooter.
[*] Not really a con, but less interesting mechanics of robots when compared to Mechwarrior. Different concept though, and may depend on taste. 
[/list]

I honestly do not know why I haven't played this game sooner, I've known the name for a long time (ever since Apex legends released cause I know the whole ordeal behind that...) I've heard how good this game is and how so many people want a 3rd one, and it's been in my wishlist for like 2 years now and I've seen it on sale for 5 dollars so many times now, but I only now bought it. I played this game knowing almost nothing about it besides the fact that you have a friend robot (which should've made me play even sooner considering I adore robot characters in games and media, but for some reason I still didn't). What I got, was an amazing story game with *insanely* cool gameplay mechanics that I wasn't expecting (there seriously was a moment where I got to one section of the game where you teleport between 2 different time frames and I was like "woah, this is cool." and had to stop for a minute cause I just thought it was so cool). and an amazing friendship between the main character and BT (the robot). I loved every second of this game and was so distraught when it ended cause I wanted it to be so much longer. I beat the game in a single play through and then went back and got all of the collectibles and actually 100%-ed the game just because I wanted more. I plan on coming back again sometime in the future just to play it again after it feels fresh to me. 

It's rare to find shooter games with good unique gameplay AND a good story (...Newer CoD...) so this one was a treat. I am now on the bandwagon of hoping that they make a 3rd Titanfall, but for now, I will be replaying this game and over until then. My only complaint is that it's not longer, 9.5/10.

[h1] Thank You Respawn and Apex Whales for Killing this Game and Titanfall 3 [/h1]
[i] Firstly, let me clarify that despite the negative recommendation I'll be highlighting, I am an avid fan of this game and would highly recommend it under normal circumstances (especially the story). However, my criticism is solely based on the game's current state....

This is no longer the case! This is back up and running based off the reviews, however I cannot be arsed to test if this is true. But i have my faith in the community[/i]

[h2] Actual Review [/h2]
Titanfall 2 is a first-person shooter game developed by Respawn Entertainment and published by Electronic Arts. The game was released in 2016 and received positive reviews from critics and players alike. It features a unique mix of fast-paced multiplayer combat and a single-player campaign that tells the story of a soldier named Jack Cooper and his Titan, BT-7274.

[h2] Pros and cons [/h2][table][tr][th] 🟩 Positives [/th][th] 🟥 Negatives [/th][/tr][tr][td]
-  The gameplay of Titanfall 2 is known for its fast-paced action and mobility, which gives players the feeling of being a powerful Titan pilot.

- The story of Titanfall 2 is highly praised for its unique premise and strong character development. The relationship between the player character and the Titan they pilot is a standout feature of the game.

- The movement system of Titanfall 2 is one of the game's standout features. The fluidity of the movement, combined with the fast-paced action, makes for an immersive experience.

- The levels in Titanfall 2 are designed in a way that allows players to experience the world in a variety of ways. The levels are designed to encourage players to experiment with different strategies and play styles.[/td][td]

- One of the biggest criticisms of Titanfall 2 is the length of its single-player campaign, which is around 6-8 hours. While the campaign is highly praised for its quality, some players may feel that it is too short.

- Despite having a solid multiplayer mode, some players have criticised the game for lacking content in this area.[/td][/tr][/table]

[h2]Gameplay [/h2]The gameplay in Titanfall 2 is fast, fluid, and highly entertaining. Players have the ability to control both their human pilot and their Titan, allowing for a wide range of combat options and strategies. The movement system is particularly noteworthy, allowing players to easily traverse the environment and engage in combat with both their pilot and Titan abilities. The multiplayer mode is where the game shines, offering players a variety of game modes, maps, and customisation options to keep the gameplay fresh and exciting.

[h3]Movement System [/h3]
The movement system in Titanfall 2 is one of the game's standout features. The fluidity of the controls and the ability to easily traverse the environment with both pilot and Titan abilities make for a truly enjoyable experience. Players can easily zip around the map, executing double jumps, wall running, and sliding. The movement system also plays a large role in the multiplayer mode, allowing players to quickly and easily maneuver around the map and engage in combat.

[h2] Story [/h2]The single-player campaign in Titanfall 2 tells the story of Jack Cooper and his Titan, BT-7274. While the over-arching plot may seem cheesy and typical of a Michael Bay action movie, the relationship between Jack and BT is a standout aspect of the story. The campaign's strong level design and satisfying gameplay mechanics also help to further develop this relationship, making for a truly enjoyable experience. The campaign provides about 6-8 hours of non-stop fun, making it a great option for those looking for a brief, action-packed single-player experience.

[h2] Art Style/Theme [/h2]The art style and theme in Titanfall 2 are heavily influenced by science fiction and futuristic technology. The game's environments and characters are visually stunning, with detailed textures, lighting, and animations. The game's overall theme is dark and brooding, with a strong emphasis on military technology and the struggles of soldiers in a war-torn world. The art style and theme of Titanfall 2 are well-suited to the fast-paced and action-packed gameplay, providing a truly immersive experience.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]In conclusion, Titanfall 2 is a highly entertaining game that offers a unique mix of fast-paced multiplayer combat and a single-player campaign with a strong emphasis on character development. The game's standout features include its movement system, fast-paced gameplay, and visually stunning art style. Although the game may not have the same level of popularity as some of its competitors, it is still a highly recommended title for those looking for a unique and action-packed gaming experience.

This review is specifically aims at the campaign, that I beat in probably less than 5 hours, and does not consider any other mode.

Meh.

If you get it for about 5$ then it's a reasonably good deal.

If you are looking for an intricate and deep shooter that rewards your aiming skill, that's not it. If you are looking for a Michael Bay movie mixed with the ulltimate power fantasy transformed into a shooting game with robots, that is it.

My biggest problem with this game is that I don't personnaly like power fantasy, I prefer deeper story. The main character if so FULL of plot armor, shonen protagonist would be jealous of him. I don't win fights or accomplish things because I am good at the game, I succeed because the main character is meant to win against impossible odds. You can fight army 100 times bigger than yours, just press left click and win.

The shooting, and especially the feel of many of these weapons is on par with some of my favorite shooter. The parkour is fine, the sliding is good. The mech fights, are in my opinion, boring, they are incredibly over the top, but not as deep and intricate as the shooting. 
The story is mediocre. It's the most american thing I have seen in a while. There's no great character, the voice acting is alright, the writing is poor and the pacing...
The game has a great tutorial though, I am not talking about the ghost thing at the beginning, I am talking about the first level, which slowly introduces mechanics in increasing level of complexity, which is nice.
Also, it has so many flaws, no audio mixing (I hate BT repeatedly saying I am fighting titans, when I am next to him shooting at said titan, and would've prefer to shut off dialogue volume), no option to hold to run (c'mon, now). The game crashed while opening maybe 5/6 times, and that's considering the fact that I beat the game in two sessions. Also, SO many loading screens, even inside levels, which aren't too long.

4/10, get it on sales if you have nothing else to play

Speak to any Titanfall fan, and they’ll tell you that the game’s sense of momentum is unparalleled in the shooter space. The ability to easily wall run, double jump and climb up on ledges, all while constantly on the run, gives Titanfall a breakneck pace and fluidity that has yet to be topped. Though the Call of Duty series can’t quite match the sense of speed and agility that Titanfall seems to achieve so effortlessly.

This parkour-style movement works so well in Titanfall 2 because its levels are designed to take advantage of it. Nowhere is this more evident than in Titanfall 2’s single player campaign, where the mastery of double jumping and wall running will be crucial to your success.

In Titanfall 2’s story campaign, you play Jack Cooper, a rifleman in the Militia who dreams of becoming a pilot. Jack’s dreams become true sooner than expected when an IMC attack forces his mortally-wounded mentor to transfer ownership of his Titan, named BT, over to him. Thrust into the war, the new pilot and his Titan quickly develop a bond that carries them through this violent conflict.

At first glance, the storyline in Titanfall 2 resembles the kind of generic sci-fi premise that you’d expect to see. While the story itself is far from original, the game’s humour and the unlikely friendship that grows between Jack and BT elevates the story mode into something that’s truly rewarding. You quickly believe that these characters really care for each other, which is repeatedly demonstrated by their actions throughout the campaign. In many ways, the relationship 

By now, you may have heard some comparisons to Half Life 2 thrown around in regards to Titanfall 2’s campaign, and for once, this correlation is justified. The most surprising aspect about the game’s story mode is that it manages to switch up its gameplay entirely on a level-to-level basis. Each mission, a new device or mechanic is introduced which forces you to change your approach to battles and traversal. Because of this, the campaign in Titanfall 2 never once grows stale. 

While the core gameplay ratio remains the same throughout, switching things up between on-foot and Titan-focused battles, these sections change drastically when new mechanics are introduced, such as when time manipulation or wall placement is factored in. One level sees you flipping between past and present versions of the same facility. Depending on the timeframe you’re currently in, the ground or certain walls or doors may or may not be there, and harmless scientists may be replaced by violent enemies. You’ll have to keep your wits and reflexes sharp in order to make it through. It’s one of the more refreshing first person gaming experiences in a long while, recalling the likes of Portal in its clever design. 

Titanfall 2 also has a lot of Titan vs Titan boss battles throughout its campaign. Thankfully these bosses, which are almost always voiced in an over-the-top and stereotypical way, never feel overpowered. While you may die several times while taking them on, their defeat always feels achievable. Best of all, the many Titan skirmishes that occur throughout the campaign also allow you to polish your skills for multiplayer.

During Titanfall 2’s multiplayer beta, there was a lot of fan outcry calling it a step backwards, with many feeling it took too long for the losing team to be given access to Titan drops, among other balancing qualms. Others complained about the game making players choose between a sidearm and Anti-Titan weapon (a horribly unfair decision to make, given the popularity of the game’s Smart Pistol). There are also the issues of reduced pilot mobility, the lack of Attrition mode and bots were also removed from matches, making it harder for players to rack up points.

Thankfully, many of these issues have already been addressed for the game’s final release, though some are still unresolved. Attrition mode is back, player and Titan mobility has been increased, and Titan drops now happen quicker, thanks to a change which sees players receiving a small passive amount of Titan meter every few seconds. Meanwhile, the HUD has been improved, and bots are available in certain modes such as the new addition Bounty Hunt.

Along the aforementioned modes, players can also compete in Mixtape, which constantly changes modes with each game; Amped Hardpoint, which has you stealing and protecting bases; Pilots vs. Pilots; 8v8 Mixtape; Last Titan Standing; Coliseum, Capture the Flag and Free for All.

Though some issues from the tech beta still remain, Titanfall 2’s multiplayer remains fun and addictive. There’s no season pass either, meaning every player is given access to any new map, weapon or mode for the life of the game.

Absolute best fps ever made, although the lack of balancing (buffs/ nerfs) of some titans and guns over the years make some matches feel like absolute stomps where experience players do not play for fun but instead sweat their life off on newer players still learning the game. This causes newer players to leave and veterans just trying to have fun with different titan/ weapon/ ability combinations to get frustrated. Some servers are much more balanced than others. Singapore, Tokyo and most European servers feel good to play on. I can't tell about US ones but Hong Kong is the absolute worst experience probably in any game where everyone runs CAR smg, spitfire, grenade spam, stim, cloak, tone, monarch, and brainless laser shoot ions. They basically use everything that is overpowered and not balanced in the game and just give their all to win matches in an 8 year old casual game with no real matchmaking (sbmm/ mmr) and a dwindling player-base. Titanfall 2 at its core is an FPS meant to be played casually and to have fun with the perfect movement, gunplay and just experiencing the variety of classes, factions, guns, and titans. Servers and matches where people understand that make this game amazing and satisfying to get on and get off. Modern games tend to make you frustrated and increase anxiety levels at the end of a session, mostly due to the overly competitive and toxic nature of PVP games nowadays. I don't think it should be that way but some players will to their best at ruining this game for everyone else. If that happens to you, just leave and find another match, or change servers.

Worth it for the campaign alone, but the multiplayer is hands down the best of any shooter I've played. 


Lots of fun gamemodes including a PVE tower defense option. I've been playing since the beta on PS4 and just recently switched over to PC and it remains one of my all time favorites. The movement is so fluid and both titans and pilots feel fantastic despite how different their respective playstyles are. 

The multiplayer is a little intimidating for newer players but if you spend some time in campaign getting used to the movement, shooting mechanics, and abilities it becomes a lot more enjoyable. There's a very rewarding skill curve to climb that makes you feel like you're always learning and improving while still keeping things relatively balanced with other players. You will get destroyed some, but there will also be plenty of moments that make you feel godlike. I cannot sing this game's praises enough.

My only complaint is that I wish the developer would throw some more resources at it. Official servers were down for a while due to DDOS attacks and you still run into trolls and hackers every once in a while. The community has held strong and while there's definitely a competitive streak, it's a pretty supportive and fun group overall. 

This is the pinnacle of multiplayer shooters and it's hard to even imagine how a studio could top this. I hope to spend many more matches fighting for the frontier!

Titanfall 2 stands out as one of the besti if not, THE best in the genre. Its gameplay is incredibly smooth and fast-paced, making each session both a ton of fun and rewarding. The balance between the single-player campaign and multiplayer modes is exceptional. The mechanics, particularly the wall running and mech controls, is a different twist to the typical FPS experience. What really impressed me was the single-player campaign it's engaging, well-developed, and easily one of the best FPS campeigns of all time. Titanfall 2 is  a  fun, competitive MP, with a  top-notch mechanics thats fun to learn.  It always infuriated me how little attention this gem of a game got when it was released. It sort of lives on through Apex but this game is a blast in its own right and should be played by everyone.

Titanfall 2 is a masterclass in first-person shooter gaming, delivering an exhilarating experience that sets it apart from the crowd. From its breakneck-paced gameplay to its compelling characters, Respawn Entertainment has truly crafted a gem that stands tall in the world of gaming. 

The heart and soul of Titanfall 2 lie in its characters, and none shine brighter than the indomitable BT-7274. The bond formed between the protagonist, Jack Cooper, and his Titan is nothing short of extraordinary. BT's stoic yet endearing personality elevates the narrative, turning what might seem like a conventional story into a heartwarming journey. The emotional depth achieved in the relationship between Jack and BT adds layers to the plot, transforming what may appear initially bland into a rich and engaging narrative. 

Speaking of gameplay, Titanfall 2 doesn't just meet expectations; it shatters them. The fast-paced, adrenaline-fueled action is a breath of fresh air in a genre. The fluidity of movement, the seamless transition between on-foot and Titan combat, and the sheer intensity of battles create an experience that is both challenging and immensely enjoyable. 

The multiplayer component of Titanfall 2 is a true standout, offering an addictive and entertaining experience whether you're flying solo or teaming up with friends. The diverse range of maps, the strategic depth of Titan combat, and the variety of game modes ensure that each match feels fresh and exciting.

In conclusion, Titanfall 2 is a triumph in every sense of the word. It seamlessly blends intense gameplay with a touching narrative, and the characters, especially BT, leave an indelible mark on players. Respawn Entertainment has not only delivered a stellar sequel but has set a new standard for what a first-person shooter can achieve. Titanfall 2 is a must-play for anyone seeking an adrenaline-pumping, emotionally resonant gaming experience.

Titanfall 2 has received widespread acclaim from both critics and players for its engaging gameplay, compelling narrative, and innovative mechanics. Here are some positive reviews highlighting the game's strengths:

Engaging Single-Player Campaign:
Titanfall 2 is often praised for its well-crafted single-player campaign. Critics and players appreciate the compelling story, dynamic characters, and the perfect balance of intense action and emotional depth. The campaign is often cited as one of the best in the first-person shooter genre.

Innovative Movement Mechanics:
The game's unique movement mechanics, including wall-running and the use of a jetpack-like device, add a layer of dynamism to the gameplay. Reviewers have commended these features for providing a fresh and exhilarating experience, setting Titanfall 2 apart from other shooters.

Balanced Multiplayer:
The multiplayer component of Titanfall 2 has been praised for its fast-paced and well-balanced gameplay. The inclusion of giant mechs, or "Titans," adds a strategic element to matches, offering diverse playstyles and keeping the multiplayer experience engaging and unpredictable.

Stunning Graphics and Design:
The game's graphics and level design are often cited as visually impressive. The environments are well-crafted, and the attention to detail in both character and Titan design contributes to an immersive gaming experience.

Excellent Sound Design:
Titanfall 2 is noted for its exceptional sound design, enhancing the overall gaming experience. The sound effects of weapons, Titans, and the environment contribute to the game's sense of immersion and intensity.

Responsive Controls:
The game's controls are frequently praised for their responsiveness and intuitiveness. Players appreciate the smooth and precise handling, which is crucial for a fast-paced shooter like Titanfall 2.

Active Community and Support:
The game has maintained an active and dedicated player base, and ongoing support from the developers with updates and additional content has been well-received. The commitment to the community has contributed to the game's longevity.

Value for Money:
Many reviews highlight Titanfall 2 as offering great value for its price, with a well-crafted single-player campaign, engaging multiplayer, and ongoing support, making it a worthwhile investment for fans of the genre.

Overall, Titanfall 2 is often regarded as a standout title in the first-person shooter genre, earning praise for its innovation, storytelling, and overall quality.

The pinnacle of movement shooters. The gameplay is fast, energetic, and yet precise. You will still hit your shots going eleven miles per octosecond, and adrenaline is always guaranteed for every match, as standing still or even just moving slightly leisurely means death, no ifs, no buts. Every weapon feels reliable, and this is the only game where the sniper is not annoying to play against, which is due to the schmooves you can pull off. So you will not get sniped across the map unless the player has the actual skill to pull it off.

The campaign story itself is nothing special; what (at least for me) made the narrative compelling was the characters of BT (your titan) and Jack Cooper (the player) and how they grow a strong bond between each other. Also, BT is funny and adorable at the same time. Although I like Blisk as the villain (mostly because I love JB Blanc), he is not super memorable, as goes for the rest of the cast. Okay, Viper is pretty rad, but that is only because of his Titan design! Lastly, the soundtrack is unforgettable; there is nothing catchy. This does not make the game worse or bad; it just could have been much better. I will say that the composer, Stephen Barton, clearly improved, as the Apex Legends main theme is pretty good and has a memorable beat.

Either way, this game rules! If you are into fast-paced games, and especially movement shooters, this is a no-brainer. A campaign with a good narrative combined with great multiplayer for 30 euros is an absolute steal. As BT would say, "trust me."

What a fantastic game! I knew I liked it the first time I played it but playing it again just brought it all back. For a campaign that really isn't all that long it is just packed with some of the coolest set pieces I've seen. I would say that Titanfall 2 deserves it's place as one of the greatest single player shooter campaigns up with the likes of Half Life and Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare. 

I may never have gotten into the multiplayer but from what I can tell it was also really good! I'm not sure how the online is working right now because I hovered over multiplayer for a good while and it was just trying to contact servers and never made it.

Even without multiplayer this game is worth your time. I can see myself playing this once a year just like I do with FEAR. The whole game almost feels like you're treating yourself. It's just a joy to play.

i get that this is supposed to be an amazing movement shooter which it is, but i cant find myself having any fun with this. played for hundreds of hours on console years ago, picked it up awhile ago on steam only to get rofflestomped by Gen 40+ average every match. 

there's no real matchmaking for newer players, they casually drop fresh installs in with people who've played for hundreds if not thousands of hours. dropping players into the deep end will force players to learn quick yet it can also make them leave just as quickly and be seen as being not ''noob friendly'' just like TF2... The one by valve. (but that one's determined by the server you join so eh)

I've also noticed i tend to clip on edges of walls essentially killing all my momentum leading to my death. 

TL;DR = I'm crying cus im bad, there should be matchmaking for new players/fresh installs but there isnt, clipping issues killing all speed. 4/10 would not play again: Nostalgic filter from console days makes it seem appealing when it isnt, alongside very poor matchmaking.

For the multplayer.
Solution!
If you have an Intel CPU, this is what fixed it for me and other people:

 

Press Win + E or open File Explorer, right-click on “This PC,” and choose “Properties.
Click on “Advanced System Settings.”
Under the Advanced tab, choose “Environment Variables.”
Under “System variables,” click on “New.”
In the “Variable name” box, type this: OPENSSL_ia32cap
In the “Variable value” box, type this: ~0x200000200000000
Then click on “OK.”
Confirm the addition of the variable to the “System variables” list and choose “OK.”
Restart your PC.

For years, the little I've heard of this game was nothing but high praise. I didn't try it when it was new bc the advanced movement seemed like it would be over my head. Still, I followed the TF|2 news and the hacker drama. I picked this up in October (2023) after hearing that the vanilla servers were miraculously and suddenly returned to life.

I was a fool for waiting almost seven years.

I was legitimately addicted to this game for the entirety of that first month. The campaign slaps. The gameplay is solid, polished, and feels oh so good. And the balance - while not perfect - is held to higher standards than the vast majority of the competition. 

...just don't expect to immediately rip-and-tear in online lobbies. The dedicated fanbase has a little bit (many, many years) more experience than us newbies, and that tends to stack up exponentially in advanced movement shooters. Play the campaign. Get comfortable with wall-running. Don't be afraid to fail. And don't be afraid to ask for tips. The majority of the playerbase is really friendly, and there's a good amount of videos online that are still up-to-date even if they're several years old. 

So standby for Titanfall, and get ready to cope about the Titanfall 3 release schedule with the rest of us.

After finally gathering enough courage I bought Titanfall 2 from Steam sale. It's awesome. The campaign is fun and has  depth, while the multiplayer is great fun in different way.  While the learning curve is a bit steep at first, after getting past the first threshold of knowing how to operate both the the pilot as well as the mech effectively everything feels fluid. Of course you'll get mopped the floor with by those who've got hundreds of hours more game time under their belt but it's great when you notice how your movement is getting better and you're getting more and more kills. 

In multiplayer, you won't have trouble finding matches. The queuing time for a match depends but usually it's less than two minutes to find one.  I can honestly see myself playing Titanfall 2 for hundreds of hours. If you've ever played Apex Legends, you'll recognize the weapons and the mechanics even. I've got about 500 hours in Apex Legends but I honestly can't say I'll go back to Apex Legends after getting to know Titanfall. You can lay back and relax and chill and have fun in Titanfall without all the raging of the Apex Legends. It's such a mystery why the game studio behind both of the games thought to go forward with Apex Legends instead. 

Seriously, try it for yourself. It's just that fun!

This game has now a special place in my heart. The gameplay, the story and the characters they were all awesome.

Titanfall 2, for me, is a masterpiece...

It is kind of sad that EA or Respawn has not seen our request to make Titanfall 3, because this game was FANTASTIC.

SPOILERS AHEAD! SPOILERS AHEAD! SPOILERS AHEAD!

The Idea of having a companion with you in games, is not rare, many games have done that. But, in this game, BT-7274 (Bravo-Tango 7274) is a perfect mix of a friend and a robot.

There are many dialogues that indicate that BT is FAR MORE than a robot. During typical games with robots as companions, the most common play is that the robots are pretty dumb where they do not understand sarcasm. BT, in chapter 1, being the same, with a formal tone, and, not understanding sarcasm, but, as the main Protagonist (Jack Cooper) and BT become close, we can see that BT understands things.

One Crucial moment that I spotted out was in the chapter where we were about to escape with the Arc, but, we got trapped inside the ship which was quickly crashing. In that scene, BT covered Jack with some debris and his own chassis, and, when we asked about what he was doing, he responded with "Protocol 3: I will not lose another Pilot". Anyone familiar with the game will remember that Protocol 3 was "Protect the Pilot", not, "I will not lose another pilot". This clearly shows that the story writers have put a lot of effort into BT's Character.

And also, one last spoiler, that, in the end, where BT dies, Respawn makes sure that not just Jack Cooper will miss BT, the PLAYER will also miss BT.

I would like to tell EA and Respawn to PLEASE make Titanfall 3

The campaign is short, but that works to its advantage in my opinion. The locations are varied and interesting and there are a good amount of different missions to get through. Some of these focus more on combat, others more on traversal. The best one is the chapter "Cause and Effect", which features an unexpected mechanic that makes going through the level a lot of fun. 

Although your Titan (BT) stays the same, there are different types of loadouts you unlock. These change the abilities and weapons of BT and keep the shooting feeling fresh throughout.

Story-wise it's a pretty standard affair, but it is immensely helped by the dynamic between you and BT. There's some fun dialogue and genuinely good moments sprinkled throughout. Even if it’s just for the campaign I’d definitely say it is, without a doubt, worth the discounted asking price. 

The game ran at a consistent 60 fps @ 800p (high settings) on Steam Deck and it looked amazing on the small screen.

As someone who played Apex Legends first (sorry), it is an amazing experience coming back to it's roots and origins, what everything we know about in Apex came from to start with. As time went on I became much more of a Titanfall fan than Apex and now seeing any hint of Titanfall in Apex cinematics, characters, or trailers is exciting and saddening at the same time:

The story, setting and beauty of Titanfall is captivating and unique. No other game feels quite the same, but the game suffers at  the hand of its own publisher/development team. EA is responsible for the low playerbase of this game, do not take face value numbers as "this game must be bad because not many people play it".

The campaign is 10/10 and is awesome to play and help get a feel of the game before launching into PvP. Even if you have played Apex before Titanfall, like me, I would recommend playing the campaign first, as it feels extremely different, but also strangely familiar.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

What I love about this game can be summed up in one word: "Feel". This is one of those games where it seems to make everything you do feel cool. Because you're playing as a super soldier who can basically fly with the power of wallrunning and grappling hooks, who also has a giant robot buddy who makes you feel like you could take on all the Greek gods after they tricked you into killing your own wife and daughter. The singleplayer campaign is incredibly fun and well designed, and has one of the coolest levels known to gamers in the form of a time jumping mission. The multiplayer modes are super fun and don't require you to sweat out of your eyes to feel like you're doing okay (like in the sister-game Apex Legends), and even the co-op I find to be super satisfying and fun. The original Titanfall had the problem of there not being much progression or unlocks - but that is certainly taken care of in this sequel. Every game it feels like you unlock a new shader for a weapon (to show off your mastery of it) and by extension, new weapons. It simply *feels good* to be playing this game, which is the main thing I look for in a game. The only possible complaint I could have is that at some points it feels like some Titans way outclass others in multiplayer, but shocked as you may be - the whole game doesn't revolve around them. You can play Pilot vs Pilot with no Titanfall, you can play co-op and not have to feel outmatched by the enemy, so on so forth. 10/10 game for me. Thank you developers, for putting your heart into this game. Looking forward to the next TF3 tease freakout.
