Titanfall 2 is a first person shooter that delivers a good story , nice gameplay and a decent multiplayer for those that are interested. One of the main features that titanfall 2 has, is its movement style , as a pilot you have great mobility being capable of running and jumping on walls, performing quite a few tricks with your arsenal if you are fast enough, but of course the main thing about the game is the Titans. The game campaign besides its good story as mentioned earlier , it does a good job of showing the type of titans and their arsenal that  you can use in multiplayer. Speaking of multiplayer it offers both pvp and pve maps , each titan having its perks that you unlock as you play. There are very few games that deliver the same gameplay and feeling you get from Titanfall 2 , some can argue no other game does and perhaps this could be true.

Immerse yourself in the adrenaline-pumping world of "Titanfall 2," a single-player FPS that stands as one of the finest in the genre.

Pros

Level design and pacing: "Titanfall 2" leverages its dynamic movement mechanics with exceptional level design, offering a diverse range of missions that keep the gameplay fresh and exhilarating. From platforming with time jumping to navigating through a prefabricated houses facility and engaging in intense titan battles, each mission introduces something unique. The variety prevents any sense of repetition, making each mission a joy to experience. The pacing is superb, leaving players eager to discover what comes next.

Combat: The game delivers an outstanding shooter experience, elevated by the exceptional level design. The ability to run on walls and move swiftly to avoid enemy fire adds a layer of intensity to the combat. Hacking robots to fight alongside you, a diverse array of weapons, and challenging enemies contribute to the engaging gameplay. Titan battles are a highlight, offering a satisfying sense of scale and empowerment. The fusion of FPS and platforming elements elevates the combat, setting "Titanfall 2" apart in the genre.

Cons

Length: While the brevity of the game, spanning about 6-7 hours, ensures a focused and impactful experience, it leaves players longing for more. The game concludes on a high note, and the desire for additional content is palpable. While repeating the game is an option, the prospect of additional hours of this exhilarating experience would have been a welcome addition. Nevertheless, the quality of the gameplay maintains the game's perfect score.

Summary: "Titanfall 2" excels with its exceptional level design, masterful pacing, and immensely enjoyable combat. Despite its relatively short duration, the game delivers an intense and satisfying experience, earning its place as one of the best FPS games in the industry.

[quote]
[h2] "Titanfall 2" - An Unforgettable Journey with BT, Your Mechanical Best Friend. [/h2]
[/quote]

[quote]
"Titanfall 2" stands as a shining gem in the world of first-person shooters, offering a thrilling combination of fast-paced action, inventive gameplay mechanics, and a narrative that tugs at the heartstrings. At the center of this masterpiece is the bond forged with your Titan, BT-7274.

From the moment you first embark on your journey with BT, the connection deepens with every encounter. BT isn't just a machine; he's a companion, a partner in the chaos of war. The moments of banter and camaraderie between Pilot and Titan inject a surprising amount of humanity into the game, making BT more than just a mechanical sidekick.

The gameplay mechanics, seamlessly blending fluid parkour with Titan combat, are a testament to the game's innovation. The level design offers a playground for creativity, whether you're executing gravity-defying stunts as a Pilot or engaging in intense mech battles with enemy Titans.

The narrative, while rooted in sci-fi action, manages to deliver emotional punches that resonate. The dynamic relationship with BT is the emotional core of the story, creating a bond that lingers in the player's memory long after the credits roll.

In conclusion, "Titanfall 2" isn't just a game; it's an unforgettable journey where the line between man and machine blurs, and a bond with a Titan becomes a defining element of the experience. Whether you're soaring through the air or engaging in Titan warfare, the game leaves an indelible mark, thanks in no small part to the extraordinary connection with BT.
[/quote]

Really fun game and one of the best fast-paced FPS in my opinion! The controls are fluid and flexible making acting and reacting quick. This makes for nice immersive game play and works well with the mechanics of the game. Slow controls/movement in a shooter game is the last thing you want and this is anything but that. The wall running and agility of the player character are my favorite. I mostly play online multiplayer but the campaign is pretty fun too. 

Starting out in multiplayer can be a little rough because you will be playing with leveled up players who already have the weapon unlocks but it's still fun nonetheless. Once you get some experience under your belt, you can actually start helping your team with winning instead of becoming points for the opposing side lol!

This game can and will hold a special place in my heart for as long as I live, hell, maybe even longer. After hearing so much about the campaign online, I decided to purchase this game for about five dollars on winter sale. Since it gave it me almost twenty hours of action, stunning visuals, and amazing plot just in the campaign,  I could easily say that is one of the best games I've ever played. Everything in it is perfect and people online definitely did not over hype it, which is the case for some other games I've played.

The characters are a whole other thing too. BT is the most personable robot I've ever met, and Jack's voice lines are great, they reflect the situation while also maintaining a sense of humor. The 6-4 crew, even if we only met them for a bit, were a great way to make invading a ship with countless amounts of enemies, just a bit more fun and lighthearted. The boss battles are great and always provided a hit of adrenaline. Plus, the box characters all had different personalities and styles of fighting, that way it didn't get stale. All of the other characters where notable too, I just don't feel like writing it all out.

The missions were astounding as well. They weren't too hard of too easy, and while you could complete them with ease on normal mode, it was more a relaxing playtime rather than something like Only Up, where you contemplate killing yourself over the smallest mistake. My favorite mission had to be the final one, where you witness BT get killed, and then see him reappear just in time for completing your boss fight. While this is a video game, I was still at the verge of tears when BT sacrificed himself for protecting the pilot. The scene before the credits basically summed that up for me. I didn't feel good about BT dying in the end. 

The visuals are also something to be reckoned with. The first hour I played the game, I was just drooling over how good the graphics looked and how they pair so nicely with the plot. Even if the game was made in 2016, I honestly think that it rivals most of the modern hits like Cyberpunk. 

So far, I have absolutely no complaints about the game, and I am exited to try the multiplayer feature. I have heard that its absolute dogshit, but I don't think that that's possible considering how good the rest of the game was. Even if the multiplayer is garbage, I think that Respawn deserves all of the credit that anyone can give them. Great game guys, and I hope we get to find out how that post credits scene might tie into a third game. ;)

Titanfall 2: A Masterpiece of Storytelling in the World of Mechs

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Titanfall 2, developed by Respawn Entertainment, not only stands out as an exceptional first-person shooter but also captivates players with its unexpected and remarkable narrative. Released in 2016, this game takes the Titanfall franchise to new heights, particularly in terms of its gripping and emotionally resonant story.

From the outset, Titanfall 2 distinguishes itself with a unique blend of heart-pounding action and a narrative that delves deep into the bond between a pilot and their Titan. The protagonist, Jack Cooper, finds himself unexpectedly paired with BT-7274, a Vanguard-class Titan, after the original pilot is killed in action. What follows is a rollercoaster of emotions as players navigate a hostile alien planet, facing not only enemy soldiers but also the challenges that arise from the evolving connection between Jack and BT.

The pacing of Titanfall 2's story is impeccable, seamlessly transitioning between intense firefights, parkour-inspired pilot movements, and heartfelt moments between the protagonist and his mechanical companion. The writing is sharp, injecting humor into the dialogue without sacrificing the gravity of the overarching plot. This balance contributes to a narrative that is not only entertaining but also emotionally engaging.

One of the game's strengths lies in its ability to deliver unexpected twists and turns. The story takes players through a diverse range of environments, each with its own set of challenges and surprises. Whether navigating a sprawling manufacturing facility or battling through the interiors of a colossal factory, Titanfall 2 keeps players on the edge of their seats with its constantly evolving gameplay and narrative revelations.

The character development in Titanfall 2 is noteworthy, especially considering the limited screen time for certain characters. BT-7274, in particular, emerges as more than just a machine, displaying a personality and charm that fosters a genuine emotional connection. This emotional resonance extends to the broader narrative, creating a memorable experience that lingers well after the credits roll.

Complementing the stellar storytelling is Titanfall 2's exceptional level design and gameplay mechanics. The game seamlessly integrates Titan combat with nimble pilot movement, providing a dynamic and exhilarating experience. The synergy between the game's mechanics and its narrative enhances the overall immersion, making Titanfall 2 a standout title in the genre.

In conclusion, Titanfall 2 not only surpasses its predecessor in terms of gameplay but also delivers a narrative experience that elevates it to the ranks of gaming masterpieces. The emotional depth, unexpected twists, and impeccable pacing make this game a must-play for both fans of the first-person shooter genre and those seeking a compelling, character-driven story in the realm of futuristic warfare. Respawn Entertainment has truly set a new standard with Titanfall 2, and it remains a shining example of how storytelling can elevate the gaming experience to new heights.

I'm only playing the singleplayer mode of Titanfall 2, and I can say that it is one of the most fun shooter experiences there is, absolutely worth testing out. The gameplay is amazingly fluent, the character glides on surfaces, makes absolutely precise shooting, and using the core abilities goes very easily. When inside the BT-mech, you get one of the most 'authentic' feelings of an agile, but heavy robot, with increasing abilites to battle in a bullet-hell. I was stuck for a while in the jumping sequence of the facility, which demands that the player understands the ore mechanics at that point of play. But when I finally passed, I (once again) was thrilled by the effort the devs put in the different landscapes, too. The sceneries are diversified, which adds to the motivation to continue. Another aspect of the game are the new weapons to aquire - when you think you found your favorite, there certainly comes a new one to take its place. Great shooter experience!

I will say I hit some bugs in the campaign that were annoying. In chapter 3 the game just decided I wasn't allowed to run anymore (might happen after death by radiation, as I had radiation sounds after loading from checkpoint onwward) that reloading or restarting the game did not fix, you just had to limp through the chapter. In the 2nd to last mission I had a mission objective not mark as done and I had to restart the chapter entirely, my guess is that it did not account for sniping enemies on the other platforms and was waiting for them to die AFTER I got in range, leaving the quest waiting for a cleared platform to be cleared and no way for me to force it to move on, luckily it was relatively early into the chapter.

When Titanfall 1 came out, I was ecstatic. Giant robots, massive battles, amazing movement options, and a marketing campaign close to the Believe campaign from Halo 3 without the emotional attachment. Absolutely phenomenal. I didnt get to play it. I was a kid with no money, and no way to get the game itself. 

When Titanfall 2 came out - I missed the initial wave of players, I missed out on the launch, I missed out for a long time. 

I purchased it a couple years back just for the campaign and fell in love. I expected a game like this to be dead after 6 years, after seeming abandonment by the developers in favor of a pale imitation that pushes the standard battle royale game mode that so many FPS devs are following these days, and after the rumored Russian hacks. 

To my incredibly pleasant surprise, it was not dead. It was thriving. A welcoming, warm community of all types of people, running along walls, blasting each other to bits, piloting massive robots, and generally just having a wonderful time. 

Titanfall 2 has one of the kindest playerbases I've ever seen in my life - and that's not even the best part of the game. The best part is that it plays so immaculately well. As said by my sister who is a former Quake semi-pro "these movement options scratch an itch I've not been able to satiate in years." The gunplay is phenomenal and feels solid. When your shots hit, they HIT, when they don't - you know why.

On top of all of this, TF2's sound design rivals most anything on the market. The sounds of the weapons being incredibly distinct from one another, Titans falling from the sky, ambient noises, footsteps, jetpacks and abilities, Respawn did an amazing job working on this game, and every moment of gameplay is an audio heaven. Speaking of  gameplay - the mechanics that you learn about and have your mind slightly blown (like hacking enemy Specter Squads), and graphics that hold up well enough to this day to not feel dated, game types like Attrition, the distinct change of pace from Pilot to Titan, and the ability to not feel like you're completely out of luck facing enemy Titans from on foot - this entire game is so well made that if you like FPS and you don't have it in your library even these 7 years out from the release, you need to. As soon as you can. 

While I purchased it on sale, I'd go as far as to say that it's worth buying at the full $29.99 USD.

It's advisable to reconsider purchasing this game as the experience is likely to be challenging. Players, colloquially referred to as "no lifers," who have accumulated years of gameplay, present a formidable challenge. Unfortunately, the absence of an effective matchmaking system exacerbates this issue, failing to pair new players with others of similar skill levels. Consequently, newcomers may find themselves pitted against highly experienced individuals, making it a potentially frustrating and unbalanced gaming experience. Given these circumstances, some may argue that it's preferable to allow the game to fade into obscurity, as the current state and lack of support for new players may hinder its long-term viability and appeal.

This game is pretty much the video game equivalent of a Michael Bay movie:
- the story feels like everything is urgent, yet, doesn't really matter
- an emotional journey of militaristic nonsense
- big robots and explosions
- all that with good music

(I'm not anti Michael Bay, but these are just facts)

It's a fun game.

BUT HERE'S WHAT GREAT ABOUT IT:
- amazing graphics
- yet it's not heavy on the graphics card (great implementation)
- sound effects are very nice
- tends to be very cheap through discounts

WHAT'S NOT GREAT:
- 'EA APP' (formerly Origin) platform
- too much dialogue. We don't care about the story - nor should we. I don't think this is the game for deep lore stuff. It could have been more straight-to-combat oriented.

I'm not anti EA either. I think they deserve more respect than they currently get. I'm quite happy with:
- this title
- NFS (2015)
- Dead Space 3 (original)
- Mirror's Edge Catalyst
- Crysis 2 and 3 (original ones)

Lots of fun stuff that tends to be cheap and lightweight on graphics cards while looking amazing.
From that perspective, EA deserves more respect than Ubisoft.

This honestly is my new favorite FPS of all time. It's very well-made. Despite being abandoned by the developer and publisher, it's enjoyed a revival. 

While it takes some time to learn the movement system, it's very rewarding. Learning to zoom across the map is really quite a treat. The movement system is deep, but as long as you learn and practice some of the basics, it'll treat you well. 

Thankfully, this game supports a good variety of gamemodes, weapons, tactical abilities, grenades, and Titans. The standard gamemode, Attrition, gives NPC targets that still benefits your teams when killed so that newer and unskilled players can still contribute. However, there's plenty of other gamemodes like CTF, Pilot vs Pilot (just Pilot Gameplay), and even a Co-Op mode called Frontier Defense. 

There are 7 types of primary weapons, with at least 2, at most 4 options for each type, 3 pistols for secondaries, and 4 Anti-Titan weapons (weapons good at, you guessed, dealing with Titans). 7 Titans all with different playstyles and further options to tweak abilities. 7 tactical abilities for 7 distinct playstyles and 6 types of throwable grenades called ordinances as well. You get two other abilities to adjust your Pilot and a customizable Execution animation. Thankfully, you get up to 10 Loadouts to adjust.

There's a lot of customization, and the vast majority of it can be unlocked just for playing. The Steam version comes with the DLC needed to try out all the gameplay aspects, only locking additional weapon, Titan, and Pilot (player character) skin options behind pay walls. 

The campaign is short, but very good. This is a great game to speedrun, but besides that, it's short and sweet. Lots of fun, designed well with both Pilot and Titan movement and combat in mind. The actual plot is... well, it's serviceable, and except for your character and your main companion, no one really gets characterization per se, but that's okay. 

Thankfully, now the game's servers have been fixed and you can play online in a Vanilla state. This game is moddable and there's also the Northstar client if you want to try out mods through that. 

It's a lovely game. If you can get it as a gift or nab it on sale, it's 100% worth your time to check out.

A lot of new players find their first games of TF2 unenjoyable, because they get stomped all round every round, but trust me, stick with it, and use frontier defense, the PVE mode. Great tool to get up to scratch

It takes a few rounds for a pro to get their T-legs in a session, and coming back after a break / starting new can feel like riding a bike with the controls reversed, but once you click it's absolutely unlike anything else I've ever played. When you figure out the movement system and how to dodge and weave titans, the shit you can pull off makes any scripted trailer look pathetic and unimaginative by comparison. Thousands of games give you superpowers but TF2, when it's really popping, makes You feel like a genuine badass. Taking out a pilot, diving for a window, dropping a satchel on the ground, sliding out the other side as you turn and pull the remote trigger to watch their friend coming after you explode, before bouncing off of a couple walls, reloading, aggroing an enemy titan which comes at you with a vengeance, sliding over cover above their heads as their rounds explode below you, slipping off the edge, catching just enough air for an Archer to target lock and then three point landing behind them as this monster that could crush you into a fine paste with a single keypress gets pounded from above and detonates, all in a single fluid line of badass movement is just a feeling you can't adequately describe with words. Knowing it's not cos you got the super amazing supergun powerup, but because you as a squishy agile lil bunny were able to outmaneuver something with the firepower to kill a battleship and snatch victory is just unbelievably kickass

Some tips: it's not just about moving fast, it's about moving fast and being able to stick close to cover, as well as having a firm grasp on the tactical situation, where the enemies are, where friendly support is, which terrain you can use to turn the tables, then using your movement skills to flip it on em

If you need to fight titans, the best thing you can do is get as much sideways movement as possible, (not head on / away) and try to only break cover long enough to make your antitian weapons hurt. Also, staying close to the ground or right up in their personal space is surprisingly effective. Once took down a ronin from full health as a pilot entirely in close quartets by making them repeatedly grasp at the air where I'd been a millisecond before. Which rocked.  If you need to go for a head on rodeo, try to do it with as much speed and as close to their legs as possible until the jump at the very last moment (obv blind spots are even better)  b/c 99% of the time they're expecting people to jump up to their mids or tops to rodeo, or to get to cover to use ATs. Use what they expect and subvert


Also if you have server issues, change from bottom left main menu. When too few people are in an area, they get kinda unstable, or struggle to matchmake, but it's really rarely a problem these days (used to be famously bad, fixed now) but even if you have to game a couple continents away my experience is you can still consistently be first if you know what you're doing cos the netcodes pretty good when servers are populated

[h1] Titanfall 2: A Masterclass in FPS Excellence [/h1]

Respawn Entertainment's "Titanfall 2" catapults players into the forefront of advanced titan technology, delivering an unparalleled experience that seamlessly blends a captivating single-player campaign with a thrilling multiplayer arena. Boasting new titans, pilots, weapons, and robust customization systems, the game transforms you and your titan into an unstoppable force on the battlefield.

The single-player campaign in "Titanfall 2" stands as a shining beacon in gaming history. Respawn Entertainment has crafted a narrative that transcends the typical expectations of a first-person shooter. The story is compelling, emotional, and expertly paced, offering a level of immersion that sets a new standard for the genre. The campaign showcases the developer's commitment to delivering not just a game but a memorable and impactful gaming experience.

The heart of "Titanfall 2" lies in its outstanding gameplay elements. The fluidity of movement, precision in gunplay, and the sheer power of titan machines create an exhilarating synergy that keeps players on the edge of their seats. The balance between pilots and titans adds strategic depth to the multiplayer experience, ensuring that every match is a dynamic and engaging encounter.

The attention to detail extends to the customization and progression systems, allowing players to tailor their loadouts and titans to suit their playstyles. This level of personalization ensures that each player and their titan become a unique force on the battlefield.

Visually, "Titanfall 2" is a feast for the eyes. The graphics are not just technically impressive but also artistically crafted, enhancing the overall immersion and impact of the game's narrative. Every explosion, titan clash, and acrobatic maneuver is a visual spectacle that adds to the adrenaline-pumping experience.

Even with all these commendable aspects, the fact that you still consider "Titanfall 2" worth the full price speaks volumes about its quality. Picking it up during a sale is a fantastic deal, but the game's intrinsic value and the sheer enjoyment it provides make it a title that transcends its price tag.

In conclusion, "Titanfall 2" is a masterclass in first-person shooter excellence. Respawn Entertainment has created a game that excels in every aspect — from its outstanding campaign to the addictive multiplayer experience. The combination of compelling storytelling, exceptional gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals make "Titanfall 2" not just a game, but a must-play masterpiece that solidifies its place in gaming history. 100% worth every penny.

Balanced? Nope. Great story? Nope. More than 2 modes? Nope. 
Mechs? Yeah.

really good game mechanics. and it has a really good story.

This game slaps, not only your face but your knee, ass, and on master your testicles with a barbed wire baseball bat.

Now multiplayer is great, I only played it on the Xbox because I owned it there first. You feel like the world is your oyster whether your in a titan or not, you can change the entire out come of a game in an instant with amazing movement and a pretty decent selection of fire arms and utility items to keep the fast paced shoot outs very enjoyable.

Now, that's not why were here of course because I'm a single player first type of player, so how's the campaign? Phenomenal. Every level is great, though very straight forward they play to the strength of the movement and gun play allowing you to fully optimize the sandbox to your own benefit. You slowly bond with a robot as tall as a house and that robot then turns people into lasagna for you. Amazing, I love BT and his relationship with Jack because we get to see it play out through the game, not just told about it from prior experiences. 

The guns? They kick, and when 8 guys are running at you full sprint fully equipped to kill you on master and your not worried because you can just bool out and erase anybody and anything in a 5 mile radius because the game just let's you do that. Every weapon is completely usable which is amazing, so many games have guns that do nothing like hitting a guy with a sock n bopper but here? Nah that shot's gonna hit and it's gonna hit hard, even the most basic pistol is completely viable all the way till the end of the game for dealing with infantry and I love it.

Most engagements slowly build to a solid pay off normally ending in a titan fight. Even though the boss is the same they all fight you in different ways leading to a climatic ending because most of the time you can use the same weapons soon after meaning you are the boss. 

The further you get the more desperate the battles become, starting with a simple assault on idf forces gone wrong turning into setting off a super weapon that obliterates the entire planet while the few survivors make it off planet just in the nick of time leaving you with not only a sudden loss but also your greatest accomplishment of saving harmony.

Of course the game isn't perfect, having a titan fall d-day near the end can be horrendously tedious especially on harder difficulties and the final boss is not nearly the hardest. I see that flying titan in my nightmares sometimes just when I think I'm gonna finally free from my internal torment please why is he so hard like my goodness. Also when wall running sometimes your character just gets...stuck in the wall? It happened a few times and resetting the game seems to be the only fix sadly. 

To wrap up, It's simply extremely fun to play. I highly recommend you play if you haven't. If you want a score 8/10 "Wall running while auto aiming is my secret kink"

The Campaign is great, if what I would consider a little short. The graphics are brilliant and some of the scenery is breathtakingly beautiful... even if it's actually toxic electrified gas that will kill you in 2 seconds or less.

Mechanic-wise, you can change your loadout in the campaign on the fly, allowing basically seamless gun and perk changes as you fight. One minute you're a lock-on missile launching demon, the next you're unleashing a devastating laser on everything in your path.
Loadtimes are relatively quick and the story is easy to follow. Some of the campaign characters are unfortunately a bit tasteless (one female commander wearing far too much make-up to be believable in a warzone). The main characters you'll focus on and love anyway.

Very entertaining and brilliant game with a decent story and (mostly) amazing gameplay. 
I fervently enjoyed playing the game and can honestly say that it is great fun. 

BUT
And there is always a but…

1. The game may not be too short, but one may argue that it is too short for the retail price. I got it at a massive discount and actually enjoyed having a 7-ish hour well-designed campaign to play through rather than boring 20-hour mediocrity. 
2. Parkour. There are a lot of levels that just feel incredibly (and tediously) dragged out by forcing parkour into the game (or wall running/jumping). Those moments are the worst in the game and I honestly feel like the game could have been much better without these elements or with at least fewer of them. 
3. I may be asking too much, but I would love for there to be a way to play with the games weapons, because the game sometimes throws rare weapons at you and never give you a fighting chance to properly use them. 

Overall, a great game that could be improved, but…

Neat game. I played it for awhile before servers went down, used to be cracked, but now I have a skill issue.
Also, don't listen to the people comparing it to Apex. Apex is a battle-royale focused game, and Titanfall is not. That's like comparing tomatoes and cheese.
"Oh, they don't have the same abilities that make the game so much more interesting and varied." It is literally a TDM focused game. Your focus isn't going to be on when your ability is going to recharge, it's going to be on gunplay and parkour.
If you can make it past the sweats and no-lifes playing the game, you might end up having a decent amount of fun. I think it's cool.

I played a bit of the first game, but I got the sequel because people said the single player campaign was good. They were right. That's a pretty awesome campaign with some really nice ideas and epic moments. It gives you the power fantasy of riding a Titan that you rarely get on multiplayer (at least if you're as bad as I am). Shoutout to one of missions which involve [spoiler]time travel[/spoiler]

93% Score - Finished at 5.5 Hours

For what I review this game's campaign, it's an instant buy with a cheap price tag. You're getting more than what its worth!

Gameplay (2.5/2.5): Respawn does an amazing job making fluid combat movement mixed with multiple gameplay devices and FPS moments. Works better than most modern day shooters.

Story (2/2.5): The story isn't anything special. It feels very inspired by Star Wars but with Halo aesthetic if that makes sense. It all works well and feels like its own world while being familiar to that kind of story and tone. But it felt satisfying especially after bonding with BT, the mech you'll be riding along with on your missions. Quick story, replayable, played on hard and would encourage others to too.

Visuals (2.25/2.5): For a game that's 7 years old, met by impressive world-switching moments (which we do to impress others in 2023 gaming) it's damn impressive. Character models look very outdated, but the world looks gorgeous along with all the metals you'll see. Some of the smaller moments stand out too.

Audio (2.5/2.5): Audio perfection. I haven't heard more immersive gun SFX. While also played by an amazing score, not worthy of playlist material for me, but damn good at keeping you invested in the world and the campaign.

I liked it a lot, but it is not the best thing ever some reviews might lead you to believe.


Good:

-Graphics still look really good.

-The movement is, even now, some of the best in gaming.

-Interactions between Cooper and BT are compelling and are the heart of the story.

-Really good and interesting ideas which don't overstay their welcome.


Bad:

-Whilst the heart of the story is good, the overall story is cookie cutter at best. Other than Cooper and BT, nothing is interesting or compelling.

-The gunplay is serviceable. It does it's job and that's about it. Lack of variety, some sound like toys and such just don't make it a part of the game that can stand on its own like the examples above.

-Titan gameplay isn't as enjoyable as it could have been. Sure, your firepower increases when you're in a titan. But your size and slow movement just make you a big target. Not as epic as the trailers and the opening cutscene would make you believe.

-Hit-scan enemies/weapons. I don't think they fits in this game. The game gives you all these amazing movement mechanics but, in some cases/difficulties, the moment you pop out of cover, the enemies will gun you down. 
I just think that if this game had projectile based weapons/enemies, it would make the gameplay more focused on running and gunning and not just "COD with advanced movement". 

-The price is rather steep. Took me about 6 hours to finish the game with all collectables, which for £24.99 I just don't think is worth it. Though I did buy the game on sale for £3.12 which I absolutely think is worth it.

In conclusion, whilst this isn't one of the best games of all time, it sure is a damn good game. 
Grab it on a sale and I'm sure you'll enjoy it.

A fun and fast-paced shooter featuring cool mechs! The gameplay shifts seamlessly between combat taking place on-foot and while in your robot's driver's seat. While running around as a pilot, you're essentially an elite soldier, running laps around the enemy with sprinting, cloaking, sliding, wall-running and jumping. Mech combat is relatively slower, but with powerful equipment making for exciting fights against enemy mechs. 
In the single-player story, you are also provided with a large robot friend who will support you through everything - what's not to like?
If you are a big robot enjoyer, there's really no reason not to buy this.

The campaign may be good but when it comes to the multiplayer, I'm not really a big fan of it. Don't get me wrong, the titans and tacticals are pretty cool but the 6v6 is what really kills it for me. Having so many pilots running around and roaming in their huge titans really makes this a chaotic nightmare to say the least. I be constantly dying left & right because of how many pilots & titans there are. And whenever I get inside my titan, I only be in it for like 1 minute because there are just so many people attacking me. And to make matters worse, people can respawn in an instant. Making it a guaranteed for you to deal with people 24/7. So 6v6 + instant respawn = absolute chaos.

Now, aside from the gameplay, there's also a few bugs I wish to point out. For 1, this game doesn't launch in fullscreen. I mean you can set it to fullscreen in the settings but for some reason, it doesn't save it. Like I would quit the game but when I get back into it, it launches in windowed mode. Sometimes it launches in fullscreen, sometimes it doesn't. I don't know. Very strange bug to say the least.

Now, for the 2nd bug, it has something to do with my mouse sensitivity. Like I would play the game as usual but then, out of nowhere, my mouse sensitivity gets altered. Including my mouse cursor speed. I don't know why this happens but either way, this game messed up my mouse somehow. Oh well, though.
Edit: Okay actually, my mouse is now fixed. I just restarted my PC and now my mouse is back to normal. I did restart it once but the mouse was still altered for some reason. I guess the reason why this time it is fixed is because Titanfall 2 is uninstalled. But either way, this bug needs to go.

Also 3rd bug. You can't connect to the servers. It would constantly say, "Contacting Respawn servers..." but it just does nothing. Luckily, there's a fix for it I found on YouTube by MaxPixel Gaming. But still, this should not exist. Like come on Respawn.

So yeah, buggy game. Chaotic multiplayer. Constantly gonna get 3rd partied in there. Or maybe I just suck at the game. Do I suck at the game? I don't think I do. But either way, I don't like having 2 titans & a pilot attacking me all at once. Like that is some gay stuff right there.

P.S. You can't turn off blood & gore in this. Thought I point that out.

Fast wall-running shooter with giant mech battles, whats not to like?

Edit: This game only gets better. Even when you're losing you're having fun. Wallrunning deserves it's own chapter in video game movement history. Combine wallrunning and grapple and your amateur spiderman dreams are coming true. You feel powerful vs fully shielded titans, knowing you can move and deal real damage.

Nothing is cooler than directing a titan from orbit to crash onto your enemy. Pilots feel like real dangers when piloting a Titan as well. And even when you lose you get to jam around the map and blow stuff up.

The learning curve is generous to all players too. Sure you'll die a lot, but you won't care as much because it's still fun.

Strictly speaking on the campaign, this is the most lore-dense, emotional, and thrilling campaign of any multiplayer-focused game I have ever played, and dare I say, it's a masterpiece. Trust Me.

I came into Titanfall 2 for one reason: To play the campaign. It's only 5 hours or so, and you can find it on sale for 5 bucks or less, I've always heard good things... I knew from my gaming history that I would have fun with the movement, and enjoy its mechanics for the short runtime before I ran off to play other games. But I was not expecting a masterpiece. Just the campaign of Titanfall 2 is a masterpiece. And now I am terribly sad that Apex Legends exists, instead of more of this...

You might be thinking I'm a bit crazy. After all, the analogous action to this is like picking up a Call of Duty game for the campaign. Those have never been the focus. Sure, they're good experiences that acclimate you to mechanics, preparing you for the multiplayer, but I always found them a bit shallow and one note. I heard Titanfall 2 was different. I'm happy to report that it is not just different but in an entirely different league. It's still short, at about 5 hours. But what it manages to accomplish in that short time is so absolutely impactful, so engaging, and so fun, that I can't help but gush about it.

First off, the gameplay is still smooth as butter, and the graphics are absolutely pristine, I feel it can all compete with stuff that's been released this year, 2023. Areas and factions have their own theming, guns are detailed, sound incredible, and feel great to use. The movement mechanics are beyond addicting, running on walls, and killing enemies as fast as you can, it is divine. Everything you would expect from a AAA shooter is dialed in to perfection here, and as a movement shooter, it all comes together in an absolutely perfect little package that I really believe every gamer should have the chance to try. It's all so good.

I found the story to be quite captivating, and the characters (especially BT-7274) to be incredibly charming. BT especially had a huge impact on me as a character, and it was incredible how alone I would feel in the missions without 'em. The range of emotions I felt over the course of my playtime is no doubt influenced directly by the expertly done score that accents your adventure every step of the way, not to mention the bewildering efforts of the voice cast throwing passion behind every line.

The set pieces really help set the game apart and climbing INTO a TITAN mech gives you a real sense of the scale for the areas you'll traverse, and all of it helps contextualize your journey to complete the mission. You're always finding new weapons to fight with, both on foot and in your Titan, and you even get some unique equipment to use, all of which contributes to a nicely paced, consistently fresh experience.

I still cannot believe how powerful this short campaign is. Can't stop thinking about it. Maybe movement shooters aren't your thing. Or maybe you're not up for it for one reason or another or whatever. Maybe you won't feel it in the beginning. Hold on. Let it marinate just a little longer. From my experience, I'm telling you this is something special. This is a masterpiece in its own right. Trust Me. You'll feel it.

Who knows, maybe you'll enjoy it enough to play the multiplayer (which recently got fixed!). This could add another 50 hours as a Pilot in this incredible universe. Maybe enough new players will get Respawn to make a proper third game. I don't know. But I'm fighting for as many who read this to take the first steps into the universe. Spend a few hours as a Pilot. Experience this rich story, and bask in its glory. I absolutely recommend it.

After playing for +100 hours, I've come to the conclusion that this game is just for those seeking high speed gameplay mixed with wallrunning and being a total sweat in multiplayer. I can safely say that, despite the great graphics and the story and the campaing and all that, what's worthwhile here is only if you TRULY devote yourself to this game and this game only (well, unless you're hellbent on also speedrunning the tutorial gauntlet for the best time, but that's besides that). 

For me, I realized the moment this game is dead to me: the recent DoS attacks and the negligence in part of Respawn and EA. They really don't give 2 sh#ts to this already not-so-well-known game.

Edit: I *did* forget to mention, however, that if you're interested into the main story, I completely recommend it. it's no cinematic masterpiece, but the main cast is great, it has its comedic and serious moments, and the ending will make you cry, guaranteed. Plus, some difficulty options and the usual optional maguffins for cheevos. As for the multiplayer, in a nutshell, yeah it blows, moreso after only having, as of 2023, 4k people online at most.

I gave it a shot, I gave it my time, and my time was (mostly) not well spent here. 

Bottom line: it isn't for me.

One of the best FPS campaigns I've ever played, BT (Your Titan) makes the game so much more enjoyable and is a good boy. In or out of your Titan, all the missions are great and will provide you with a lot of thrills and fast paced fun action.

The gameplay mechanics are a joy, wall running and jumping and sliding while blowing enemies away feels so smooth. The Titan play is also fluid but can feel a little slow compared to when you watch clips of them fighting each other. Lots of different Titan builds to choose from, all having different tactical benefits, and it was hard to choose a favourite.

I don't play a lot of multiplayer games these days but from what I did play it was enjoyable, with two modes. One is your standard PvP and the other is a team PvE defend the objective which was also fun.

Took me 18 hours to 100% the game, but the main story is only about 7-9 hours long depending on difficulty chosen.

This game has one of the most difficult achievements you'll face, if like me, you're not a top tier gamer. "... becomes the master" will test your patience and skill but a worthwhile foe to conquer. Just watch a video of a good route if you can't find one yourself and then improve your own skill level to match it. Took me 2.5 hours roughly but I wasn't going to give up.

Completing the campaign on Master difficulty has it's tough moments, but overall isn't too bad. I only struggled with one section and that was surviving roughly 3 waves of enemies and then escaping the section, it's difficult because it has no checkpoint and the enemies can burst you down in under 2 seconds.

Let me preface this by saying Titanfall 2 is by no means a bad game. It has a great campaign, and the multiplayer is great in theory. The only reason this review isn't positive is that it's multiplayer is extremely hard to get into, the map design is extremely hit or miss, and cosmetics are quite grindy. All these points will be outlined more in depth.
Point 1: Multiplayer
As someone who kept trying to get into the multiplayer, I can say for certain a new player will get stomped constantly. There is no SBMM, so you could go up against a veteran with thousands of hours in your first match. Nobody bothers to talk in my experience, so questions won't be answered in game and you won't make friends. It's nearly impossible to get into, as you'll get stomped 70% of the time if you don't have extreme skill from the start. 

Point 2: Map Design
This is probably going to be controversial, but some maps suck. For this review, I'll be comparing Rise and Complex. Complex is made up of long, winding hallways and open areas for titans along with normal rooms and small hallways for pilots. This allows for almost all titans to be viable. Spawns are generally good. Rise, on the other hand, has two large and open areas in corners of the map, with long, straight hallways open to the sky. From one end of a hallway connected to one spawn, you can see the other. The only truly viable titans are Northstar, Tone, and Ion. Spawns in titan modes are biased towards one team generally.

Point 3: Cosmetics
Much less of a problem, but annoying. To obtain a flat color, it first says "Unlocked After Pilot Regeneration". That's fine, until you regenerate. You get yellow, the other colors are locked behind subsequent regenerations which you wouldn't know. Some cosmetics are nearly unobtainable without using a large sum of the in game currency which is gained very slowly (like 10 matches gets you 100, 300 for one nose art). Some are gained through annoying challenges, such as "get 10 pulse blade kills" (the worst one of all) or "get 100 kills streaks with X". That and the shop only cosmetics, which is a bit overpriced.

Decent campaign for $4.50 (that's a dollar per campaign hour!), unfortunate purchase at any price higher than $20 tho.

:) I love this game to pieces.
I played it back on the ps4 and abandoned my save pretty close to the end because of some distracting life event, never had the heart to replay it because i felt bad about that. But Wow... 
The whole thing can be crushed in one day, its not a lengthy campaign, but when you think about what its going for, it really shouldn't be. It achieves everything it should and more. The multiplayer was incredible for the time i experienced it, but i come in here on this steam playthrough with a different intent. This story doesn't blow me away in the sense of it being a grand space opera, it does achieve that grandeur towards the end, but its more about the bond with your mech. BT is such an awesome character, your evolution alongside him as a pilot, and the way the different enemy pilots are teased into your sights creates amazing momentum, every boss titan and their pilot becomes a memorable encounter. I don't think its perfect, but in the way that sequels can achieve so much more than their foundations, it is a triumph. I like many others really want a 3rd game. I think Respawn have a plan for it i'm sure, but it comes after the distracting license burden of Starwars, and the distracting live service pit of Apex.

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. A fantastic shooter that has great gunplay, movement, and of course the titans. Movement is fluid and feels fantastic. Matches don't get stale even if the other team is far ahead thanks to the opportunity to turn the tide with a couple of titans. Titan gameplay is fantastic and each has their own role, with Tone keeping their distance and chipping you away with missiles, to Ronin who will try and get up in your face with their sword. The campaign is also worth your time, with a great story that is really made by the interactions between Cooper and BT. Of course there is that 1 mission that will blow your mind but I won't spoil that here. Overall a fantastic fps with value that exceeds the price.

I am very glad they fixed the servers so you can play again
Couldn't recommend enough, I have another 120 hours put into this game, via the community mod "Northstar", it's great, give it a shot if you can't find a playable vanilla lobby.

[h2]TL;DR[/h2]
This is an amazing game, a fantastically wonderful first person shooter with very freeing movement mechanics, good weapon handling, visually stunning world and a campaign with an immensely captivating story arc.

[spoiler][b]Sgt. Cooper, signing off![/b][/spoiler]
[hr][/hr]
[h3]Warning[/h3]
If reading this review gives you even the slightest urge to play the game [b][i][u]without[/u][/i][/b] reading the spoilers, dear reader, please do before reading the spoilers and potentially come back later when you have completed the game.
[hr][/hr]

[h1]The Story...[/h1]
So I heard about this game a while ago, I believe I even squinted at it when [b]Titanfall 1[/b] released but I never touched it for a few different reasons, one of them being that it was published by EA, another was the status of my wallet at the time.

I can't remember if I ever added it to my wishlist or not, and it wasn't until [b]Apex Legends[/b] released that I started become indirectly invested and interested in [b]Titanfall[/b], I started to learn about the [i][b]Lore[/b][/i] of [b]Apex Legends[/b], during which I also learned that [b]Apex Legends[/b] and [b]Titanfall[/b] were contained in the same universe![/u]
And for a time I kept playing [b]Apex Legends[/b], digging into the lore, with my interest growing and growing.

I finally made up my mind and bought [b]Titanfall 2[/b] and didn't touch it for a long, long time as it was, as previously mentioned, an EA published game, but also because at the time I was knee-deep in other games and also mostly played with friends.

Finally I decided to install it and test it out
[i]and boy, oh boy did I test it...[/i]

[h3]My first session[/h3] took me from 
[i]"interested and curious but laid back"[/i]
 to 
[i]"what the heck is this?"[/i], 
[i]"what does this thing do?"[/i]
 and [i]"how the hell do I get up there?"[/i]

Which meant I spent somewhere around 5 hours "testing" the game... and it was only 3 hours until my wake-up alarm would go off. 
[h3][i]"Oops"[/i][/h3]

What followed in the coming days was my full on head first dive into the game
The world building had me stop and inspect many a nook & cranny, a few of which lead me to a collectible every now and then, others stopping me in my tracks because of the sheer [b]Magnitude[/b] for some of the POIs and level design

The journey and the relationship of the Main Protagonist [spoiler][b]Sgt. Cooper[/b] and their soon to be partner, [b]BT-7274[/b][/spoiler], a relationship that [spoiler]started from a tragedy but goes on to grow into a beautiful partnership[/spoiler] that brought me awe and wonder, [spoiler] and eventually tears... :'( [/spoiler] 
Filled with moments that keep you on your toes, on the edge of your seat, impossible odds, breathtaking scenery, magical music that all come together like a wonderful dream.

Protocol 3: protect the pilot

Of all the things I've seen on the battlefields of the Frontier, the Pilot is the true dominant force.
Fast and agile.
Graceful, yet devastating.
Perspective, resourceful, and relentless.
A Pilot sees the world differently. Sheer walls become flanking routes.
pilots fight differently. Experienced in deception and maneuver, even overwhelming odds shift in their favor.

But what truly separates the Pilot from all the grunts and machines of the battlefield is the bond between a Pilot and a Titan.
When linked to a Titan, a Pilot can only be stopped by overwhelming force, or an equal.

I'm proud to become a Pilot and a part of Titanfall 2 community. May Titanfall series be remembered forever.

In spite of the very competitive online play, there's tons of game modes for multiplayer, including the popular coop PvE called "Frontier Defense", the TDM with NPCs mode called "attrition", and amped hardpoint which is your "hold the most objectives for the longest" format.  Learning how to use wall running, sliding, and double jumping is a really addictive part of the gameplay and gives you an edge over people who are only bringing their gunplay experience from CoD or what have you.  Titan encounters require bespoke strategies depending on the surroundings, context, and specific match-up.  They're pretty balanced.  It says I've only played 14 hours but I put hundreds of hours on origin and PS4.  Great game, I've bought it 3 times.

Titanfall 2 is like a hidden gem buried under the weight of its own launch timing. Released smack in the middle of Battlefield 1 and Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare, it didn't quite get the love and attention it truly deserved. 

The game is a rollercoaster ride of a campaign, hilarious banter with your A.I. mate BT, and a multiplayer mode that'll hook you fast. It smacks you right in the 'feels' and leaves you wanting more. So, let's give it up for the under-appreciated, sidelined gaming masterpiece that is Titanfall 2! The true titan in a world of FPS games, tragically overlooked but forever in our hearts. Go play it, and you'll thank me later. 

I hope that we will get TF3 at some point in the future.

P.S. Thank you to the unsung hero - the lone janitor responsible for fixing the servers.

Best FPS game I've played by far. Great gun play and relatively balanced. The best part by far however is the movement. If you want fly across the map at mach 5 and quick scope someone along the way, you can. The fluidity of the movement combined with the outstanding gun play make Titanfall 2 a masterpiece of game design. Then you add in calling down your titan and you get to rip through the battlefield like a bat out of hell. Not only is the multiplayer amazing; the campaign is one to remember. A great story combined with great game play makes for one of the best campaigns I've ever played. Now I will say that the servers only recently got fixed but I would not be surprised if they go down again. But until that forsaken day, pick the game up, give it a try, and enjoy the beauty of this amazing game.       PLEASE GIVE ME TITANFALL 3!!!!!

*Disclaimer - I owned this on Origin at the titles' launch and had many, many hours prior to writing this review for Steam.*

Compared to launch/when the game was still being officially supported/updated, the networking performance for MP feels like dog-water. Non-existent hit registration, constant warping/skipping. Absolutely awful. 

I can't speak for the playerbase where other platforms such as Origin are concerned at this point, but prior to hopping on to test this it had 5K via Steam. For a game that came out in 2016, thats pretty damn good to be honest. If you're a new player hopping into MP for the first time however, prepare for a very high learning curve; most that are playing at this point have been playing since inception and haven't stopped.

Regarding MP in short; viable player-base for serviceable matchmaking times (provided you queue every game type) // garbage networking performance (hit registration, player warping, ect). If you're not a legacy player, it's going to be a very rough experience. (Compounded by the aforementioned garbage networking performance.)

The single-player campaign is still up there with some of the very best ever created in the medium, and perhaps someday, when Respawn is done farming twitch zoomers for Apex money or making what is without fail the -worst- triple A PC port perhaps ever made where budget/scope is concerned, and STILL isn't fixed (Jedi Survivor), we'll get Titanfall 3. I wish I could leave an "indifferent" or "mixed" review at this point. The MP is a huge component of the game and I can't in good faith recommend the complete package.

*side note - this game runs amazing on PC, go figure*

In short - the single player campaign is amazing, and is worth your time, if only once. The lowest I've seen this game is for $2 on Steam, which is what I managed to pick it up for. 1000% worth it for this and this alone at this point.

The MP at this point is cancer laced with aids. Some of the most abject GARBAGE performance where networking is concerned regarding netplay in an FPS game sadly. It was -nothing- like it is now compared to launch/while the game was current. Spend your time elsewhere.

* For those of you who come across this review and have seen the numerous reports of individuals not being able to run the game via Steam on first boot - you MUST use the EA launcher bloatware that comes bundled with this (Origin replacement) and launch the game from that launcher AT LEAST ONCE. I got the same error trying to run the game initially from Steam. Once you do that, you should be able to freely launch the game from Steam without incident. Note however that it will *still* run that in the background as the networking/netplay services still run off that Origin backend and use EA's in-game overlay, ect. There is no way to get around this.

*edit - Almost forgot. Play Frontier Defense if you pick this up. Frontier Defense good.

Potentially the best mixture of movement and gunplay, this game is a true classic and has stood the test of time. I love this game. The ttk might be low but there's still so much outplay potential, movement tech and ways you can absolutely lose your opponent. The maps are so well designed for a game of this nature, every one with infinite movement possibilities. It's as if the maps play two completely different way when you're a pilot or when you're in your titan: this helps the games to feel fresh and never at a stalemate.

Now on to the campaign. I have nothing but praise for this too, with each mission feeling important and unique from its peers. The cool mechanics provided throughout offer interesting ways to traverse the map or kill your enemies, while teaching the player about all aspects of the game, preparing them for PvP combat.

I love and will always love this game and I can't recommend picking it up enough.

This game stands among the very best in movement shooters and mech games. The pure speed of the combat pilot's ability to maneuver the battlefield is perfectly contrasted against the hulking feeling of controlling a titan. The campaign while VERY short has a decent story and excellent level designs. There is good enemy variation and moderately challenging boss fights if you play at the higher difficulty settings. Multiplayer is generally good though the game modes available tend to get old after a few hours or so. There is no competitive mode. This game is the big brother of Apex Legends so if you've played that title before the weapons and basic movement will be familiar to you. Overall the campaign is one of my favorites having played it 5-6 times so far. The multiplayer while not something I would expect to pour hundreds of hours into is fun and enjoyable. 8/10 for the campaign 6/10 for the multiplayer. If it's on sale for >$10 just get it and play the campaign.

I'm getting absolutely NO sound through any of my Bluetooth devices when I open the game. The second the game is opened, all sound gets muted. Even from outside sources like Youtube or another webpage. I looked for over an hour trying various fixes, and the fact that there are NONE and yet people continue to have issues is appalling. I own so many other games that process their sound just fine through bluetooth. But for whatever reason, first person shooters have an issue when it comes to bluetooth audio devices. Team Fortress 2, Halo Infinite, and now Titanfall 2 gets added to my list of unplayable games because of ridiculous sound issues.


Outside of that, I love this fuckking game. I was so excited when I saw it was on sale and bought it right away. But i guess i'll have to wait to play it till these issues are no longer present or I get another speaker.

Definitely play it if you can, but don't get your hopes up if you use any sort of BT speaker or headset.

I grew up watching my sister play the original Titanfall on her XBox since its release, and I've been obsessed with the universe ever since. When Titanfall 2 released, it was finally my time to take up the mantle of Pilot, and I wasn't disappointed for a single step or wall-ride. The campaign became, and still remains, one of my all-time favorite FPS Campaigns of all time despite being relatively short and the story being relatively simple. Titanfall 2's campaign doesn't pretend to be something it's not, but rather takes the short time it has to make some of the most fun in gaming I've had in ages, and this translates into the multiplayer as well. Hell, I'm dogshit at MP and yet I find myself coming back to it time and time again, especially as I age and as the yearning for that spark that only Titanfall provides increases, DDOS attacks and lack of support be damned.

This is a game made of passion, a game built on the hardwork of the first, using each aspect to its damn near fullest in ever surprising ways. I don't think Titanfall 2 will ever leave my top 10 games of all time, unless, of course, the long-awaited sequel releases and blows me away once again.

If you play FPS games, buy Titanfall 2. It's unique movement system, paired with stellar map design, satisfying mech gameplay and a fascinating world you want more of each time you delve into it, make it one of the best experiences I've had yet. If nothing else, buy it for the campaign and the amazing relation between a Pilot and his big Robot, fighting against the odds.

Titanfall 2 is a highly underrated game that deserves more recognition. The campaign mode is engaging and emotionally captivating, with a well-written storyline and memorable characters. The gameplay is fast-paced and exhilarating, with the addition of the pilot and titan mechanics adding depth and variety to the gameplay. The multiplayer mode is well-balanced and enjoyable, with a wide range of maps and game modes to keep players engaged. The graphics and sound design are top-notch, adding to the immersive experience. Overall, Titanfall 2 is a must-play game for fans of first-person shooters.

Where to start? This game is incredible in so many ways. The campaign is a bit of a cheesey buddy action movie, except your "buddy" is a two story tall robot with guns that shoot bullets the size of mortar rounds, and yet it still has compelling and even emotional story beats. The gameplay makes you feel like a badass l, like a cross between The Doom Slayer and a ninja,an unstoppable force to anything other than a Titan or another Pilot. The graphics might not be the most breathtakingly realistic, but they are still beautiful, the style just clicks with everything else in the game.

Lastly, and most importantly, EA and Respawn, if you're reading this WE WANT TITANFALL 3!!!

Like good wine, this game has aged well. It is a must-play for any shooter fan because of its inventive game play, fast-paced action, and compelling story. The campaign is an exhilarating roller-coaster, and the smooth integration of titan and pilot combat is a masterpiece. Nevertheless, nothing is perfect. Respawn has been neglecting the game for a while, and it's evident. Although the absence of fresh content and grumpy servers are disappointing, the player base is still strong. One can only hope that Respawn will eventually release a new Titanfall 3 or continue to update the game.

This was my main game for about a year when it first game out and I loved it. It was on sale on steam for $5 so I figured I would pick it up again and give it a play through. Game seems very well done.

I was recommended this by friends and played it on xbox, didnt like it then. Got it for 5 bucks on PC, thinking that may make it better, it did not. The game is massively overhyped.

Disclaimer: I only played the campaign so that's all I'll be reviewing

Movement: The movement is good, I won't deny that. However, there's also something really clunky about it, I can't place my finger on it, but maybe it's just lack of practice. It would be improved by entirely removing the sprint function, with the pilot just moving around at top speed at all times.

Combat: Oh my word, the gunplay in this game is awful. Guns all feel lame, and they mostly feel the same, I couldn't tell you the difference between half the guns. The gunplay also hinders the movement as to effectively use most of the weapons, you have to slow down a bit, or very specifically path your movement so as to make your life easier, and it just ruins the flow.  The poor gunplay and movement are not helped by the braindead AI - they will genuinely just stand there and shoot. but they're so poor that I can literally just hide behind cover and play it like it's COD. There's no reason for me to use the movement tools or play the game well, which the game should actively be encouraging me to do, which further harms the fun. Also, regenerating health and a lack of healthbar don't suit this style of game, it really should have included something like health pickups for the pilot, not just the titan.

Story: For a game so focused on the story, the story is really lame. I don't care about the characters, I don't care about BT, the villains are awful, it violates Chekov's Gun with the main antagonist, the ending is unfulfilling, the plot lacks actual cohesion, and they just threw time travel in there? Which was really out of place and jarring. 

Graphics: For the time, the graphics are pretty good, although the faces look... pretty awful to be entirely honest, they look bad. But, overall they're decent if that's what you care about.

All in all, the game is really underwhelming, I would say buy it only if it's on some ridiculously good sale, or get in on Gamepass, but other than that, it's just not worth it.

The absolute GOAT FPS is back from the grave. 
After 2 years of the servers being hijacked by a hacker, the now 7-year old king of movement shooters got an update out of the blue. An update that not only fixed matchmaking and connectivity issues, but refreshed multiplayer playlists, addressed out-of-map exploit locations and toyed with the brains of thousands of die-hard fans through cryptic in-game messaging about the potential release of Titanfall 3. 
The history of this game is longer than a measly Steam review could cover, but all you need to know about it is one word -phenomenal. And that's putting it lightly. You're either a fan for life, or you've never played Titanfall.

Cheers to the janitor at Respawn and to all pilots: TAKE YOUR PILLS FELLAS!

Bought this game on sale and didn't think much of it tbh, thought it'll be another cliche shooter. Oh I was wrong. Titanfall 2's campaign is absolutely fantastic and a highlight of my experience. You never feel stumped in a level but don't feel like its blatantly obvious and boring. The main characters are awesome, especially BT and the story progression is smooth. You quickly grasp the mechanics and aren't spoon fed the solutions, however the option is there if you need it. 

The multiplayer is also quite enjoyable, yes you may queue with people 40 levels above you however it doesn't stop you from playing altogether which is a huge plus. Such games as Halo has a dead multiplayer fanbase and you are queued with pros and it isn't fun. All in all, there is room for improvement in the multiplayer but i still feel like the multiplayer gameplay is solid and enjoyable nonetheless.

I highly recommend this game, especially for the campaign!

Upon playing more and more, my criticism of the multiplayer has gone - in fact I'd recommend the multiplayer just as much as the campaign

Titanfall 2 is a true gem in the world of first-person shooters, combining fast-paced action, exhilarating mech combat, and a captivating single-player campaign that will leave you craving for more. Respawn Entertainment has outdone themselves, delivering an experience that surpasses its predecessor in every way.

The campaign in Titanfall 2 is a work of art. It takes you on an unforgettable journey, seamlessly blending heart-pounding firefights with an engaging storyline. You step into the shoes of Jack Cooper, a Frontier Militia rifleman who finds himself linked with a Vanguard-class Titan named BT-7274. The bond that forms between Jack and BT-7274 is nothing short of remarkable, as their interactions and evolving relationship anchor the narrative.

The level design in the campaign is a triumph. Each mission feels distinct, offering a mix of on-foot traversal, intense shootouts, and jaw-dropping Titan battles. From exploring an alien-infested facility to navigating through time-bending sequences, the variety and creativity on display are simply astonishing. The pacing is flawless, ensuring that you're constantly engaged and eagerly awaiting what lies ahead.

The combat mechanics are a standout feature of Titanfall 2. On foot, you move with incredible agility, effortlessly wall-running and double-jumping your way through the battlefield. The addition of the grappling hook adds a new layer of freedom and strategic options, allowing for creative movement and surprising takedowns. When it's time to call in your Titan, the exhilaration reaches new heights. Piloting these colossal war machines is an absolute blast, with each Titan class offering distinct abilities and playstyles. The intense battles between Titans are a sight to behold, combining strategy, teamwork, and explosive firepower.

Multiplayer is where Titanfall 2 truly shines. The fast-paced matches are a thrill ride from start to finish, with an impressive array of game modes to choose from. Whether you prefer the intense chaos of Attrition or the strategic depth of Last Titan Standing, there's something for every taste. The inclusion of AI-controlled grunts and spectres adds an extra layer of immersion, making the battlefield feel alive and dynamic. The progression system is well-balanced, rewarding both skillful play and dedicated commitment, while a steady stream of free updates and DLC keeps the experience fresh and exciting.

Visually, Titanfall 2 is a treat for the eyes. The graphics are stunning, with detailed environments, impressive lighting effects, and beautifully rendered Titans. The audio design is equally impressive, from the thundering footsteps of the Titans to the satisfying crackle of gunfire. The soundtrack perfectly complements the action, immersing you in the adrenaline-fueled atmosphere of the game.

In conclusion, Titanfall 2 is a masterpiece that sets a new standard for first-person shooters. Its captivating campaign, exhilarating multiplayer, and polished mechanics combine to create an experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end. Whether you're a fan of intense firefights, epic mech battles, or engaging storytelling, this game has it all. Strap in, pilot your Titan, and get ready for an unforgettable adventure. Love it!

Titanfall 2 is a very short and relatively easy campaign if you have played any shooters before, even on Hard difficulty which is the second to hardest. A lot of people also loved it for its multiplayer matches but those servers are mostly dead now. The traversal mechanics were fun but playing as a Titan was for a bit.

There are a range of different guns for the pilot and the Titan but they are a little on the bland side with little variety, especially since the Titan guns give abilities and some later guns are just mashes of other guns. This game did not overstay its welcome that much but it's not saying much when it's only a 6-hour campaign. Still quite disappointing considering I had heard great things about it for years.

I want to give this middling recommendation but since I cannot, I chose to warn people to tone their expectations down a bit. Only get this game for 80% off or more, especially if you do not want to attempt multiplayer.

There's a lot to this game, and I heavily recommend people buy and try it

TLDR: Amazing game, a lot of good qualities, awesome community, and great modding, but abandoned by the devs (EA & Respawn).


1. It's got a short-ish, 4-5 hour campaign, but it's almost entirely action, with almost zero moments where you aren't in control of your character. This campaign isn't the best out of all the games I've played, but it is absolutely high quality and I love it to death.

2. The multiplayer is like, for lack of better words, CoD on crack.
As you can tell by the title and poster, there are giant death mech robots called Titans, there's a lot to choose from, but you can learn about those in game.

3. There are a few weapons of each gun "class" (e.g. rifle, smg, sniper, or my favorite, grenadier) which all have a pretty solid amount of differences between them, so there's a gun for everyone!

4. The movement in this game is insane to say the least. Have you ever wanted to go mach 1 by manipulating a giant robot explosion and ping-ponging off of 7 different walls to dome some poor grunt halfway across the map? Congrats, you can learn that here! There's basic double jump, clamber, sprint, slide, etc... but the main focus of the movement is the wall-running.

5. This isn't a point of quality, it's just a tip: don't stay on the floor, and hipfire is always more accurate than you first expect (except on snipers, of course). Run really fast, get in someone's face, and either blast them with hipfire, or melee them (melee on shots, and has a massive lunge radius)

6. That's also only the half of it. There's a launcher, made by the community to fix a massive DDoS incident that has since died down, called the Northstar Client.
I wouldn't recommend installing it as soon as you get the game, as I imagine it would be insanely confusing to use if you've also not played the game before, but the creativity of the people who designed it, and participate in it, is wild.

Northstar Client functions: Modding. It lets you use client-side mods (cosmetic mods) in multiplayer games. There's regular things, like changing a skin or two to make guns look more awesome, maybe changing the voice of the ai of some of the Titans, and a few audio changes too, like a different kill sound.
Then you go into the deep end. You can change the Scorch titan into Shrek, you can turn Northstar (the Titan in the game, not the launcher client) into Whiteglint from Armored Core, hell, you can find ported models of Honkai: Star Rail characters last time I checked.
You can find all of this by googling "Thunderstore Northstar Client" and that's where the massive mod database is kept (or on the Northstar discord as well)

7. Speaking of the community creations, the people that play Titanfall are some of the most fun players I've met, except for Deep Rock Galactic. If you have a question, someone has an answer.

Overall, this is a great game with many amazing facets to it, and you should definitely buy it whenever it's on sale, or even if it's not (only $20 at full price!). Try it out, worst that could happen is you refund it after a little bit of gameplay, but at least you tried out the giant space mech game.

[code]I have played Titanfall 2 before on my PS4, and I've spent quite a lot of time playing multiplayer on it. Therefore, I'm reviewing this game from the multiplayer experience only. There's already good reviews about the singleplayer content available in this game, so just check them out.[/code]

I absolutely adore the multiplayer aspect of this game. They've nailed everything I wanted in a first-person shooter game. You can customize your loadout the way you want, there won't be any weapons/tactical/boosts/kits locked behind a certain class. You are free to create your own and run with it. The games are quick and you're thrown into action right away. From start to finish, you will be facing head-to-head with other players and their titans, giving you no downtime or any boring part of the match. You are rewarded at the end of each match whether you win or lose. Its the classic player progression wherein the only way to unlock the advanced loadout, is for you to keep playing the game. You don't need to use your credit card to get an advantage. Even though the loadout seems overwhelming at first, its not. It is very simple once you get to know things around. It doesn't complicate your options, its as basic at it can be, and its fun that way. Just pick your preferences and go on have fun with it.

In a market full of Call of Duty and Battlefield, Titanfall stands tall with the rest of them. Due to the recent surge of players and release to Steam, I hope this game gets the attention it truly deserves. It is one of those rare games nowadays where you feel great for winning, but doesn't leave you irritated when losing. Because at the end of the day, all it matters is you had a great time playing, and this is what Titanfall 2 offers...

Titanfall® 2 is an adrenaline-fueled masterpiece that's set a new standard for first-person shooters. From the heart-pounding campaign that blends gripping storytelling with jaw-dropping gameplay to the seamless transition between pilot and Titan, every moment in this game is pure gaming bliss. The movement mechanics are unparalleled, offering a thrilling and dynamic experience unlike any other. The multiplayer battles are intense, strategic, and incredibly satisfying, ensuring endless hours of excitement. Respawn Entertainment has truly crafted a gem that deserves every bit of praise it receives. If you're a fan of action-packed shooters, Titanfall® 2 is an absolute must-play that delivers on every front. It's a game that leaves you breathless and eager for more. Easily one of the best gaming experiences out there!

In its purest state, RDX is a white, crystalline solid, and when mixed with plasticizers and other ingredients it makes C4. RDX can be stably stored and is considered one of the most powerful explosives used by the military. One of the most alluring factors presented by RDX for military application is RDX requires a detonator, is resistant to detonation by small arms fire, and is 1.5 times more powerful than TNT (Trinitrotoluene).
