For all intents and purposes, other than commercial, it is illegal for you to own C4. You have been warned…do not make this shit until after SHTF.

HIGH ORDER EXPLOSIVES
High order explosives are pretty easy to make when used with a basic understanding in chemistry, aside from the nitric acid used in high explosives. High explosives generally detonate because their molecular structure is made with fuel and three or more nitrogen dioxide molecules e.g. TNT (trinitrotoluene) – when a shock passes through a trinitrotoluene molecule the NO2 bond is broken, and oxygen combines with fuel.

 

How to Make C4 with RDX
Unlike other high explosives you can make RDX with this simple method, with the exception of the ammonium nitrate. All necessary precautions should be taken to prevent injury or death. Below I’ll list the equipment and materials you’ll need to make RDX.

Equipment needed to Make RDX
500 ml beaker
Glass stirring rod
Funnel and filter paper
Ice bath container
Thermometer
Blue litmus paper
Protective Eyewear (DeWalt)
Protective Suit
Face Mask
Related Video: … the impending collapse of the US food supply system will steal the food from your kids’ tables…

Materials need to make RDX
Hexamine (can substitute with Methenamine)
Concentrated Nitric Acid
Distilled Water
Table Salt
Ice
Ammonium Nitrate
How to make RDX
Place beaker in ice bath and carefully pour 550 ml of concentrated nitric acid into beaker.
When acid cools to 20 degrees below centigrade, add small (pea sized)amounts of crushed hexamine tablets into the beaker.
The temperature will rise after adding the hexamine; continue to slowly stir the mixture with your glass stirring rod.
Do not let the mixture go above 30 degree centigrade or you’re fucked. Add ammonium nitrate to the liquid bath to cool it down faster.
Add more ice and salt into the ice bath to bring the temperature of the mixture to below 0 degrees centigrade. Maintain the temperature for twenty minutes (set timer)
Pour mixture into a liter of crushed ice, shake and stir mixture like a martini.
Allow the mixture to melt, once melted use your funnel and filter paper to extract the crystals while disposing of the corrosive liquid left over.
Bring a half liter of distilled water to a steady boil and add the crystals.
Immediately filter the crystals out again and test with blue litmus paper (you want it to stay blue), repeat steps 8 & 9 and the blue litmus paper stays blue.
Allow RDX crystals to be thoroughly dried before storage.
HOW TO MAKE C1 AND C4
You may opt to make C-1 which is a bit easier to make than C-4. C-1 is made by using 88.3% RDX, 11.1% mineral oil, and 0.6% lecithin by weight. Kneed these materials together in a plastic bag to desensitize the explosive

C4 can be made with the same technique while substituting materials such as; 91% RDX, 5.3 dioctyl sebacate as the plasticizer, 2.1% polyisobutylene (or synthetic rubber) as the binding agent, and 1/6% mineral oil.

In closing…
As with many of our other articles you take on all risks, and hold allselfsustained.com harmless for any damage to property, injuries, or loss of life. By no means are you to attempt to make this without proper training, and permits. This guide is solely meant for use after TEOTWAWKI (the end of the world as we know it). Furthermore, as we’ve seen in our DIY: How to make Thermite Grenades for Vehicle and Equipment Disabling article, the comments section is a wealth of additional information. If you have any extra input, feel free to comment below.

Came back after many years and was kind of underwhelmed. I can see why Titanfall 2 wasn't huge. It is overrated for sure. It's not bad, not at all! It's one of the better FPS games and campaigns I've ever played, but it's got plenty of shortcomings. TF1 has a superior aesthetic design and personally I liked the movement more although TF2 added in the slide which is pretty much a must have. The titans are better in TF1 though with their customization instead of this class based design. Pilot movement felt weirdly slow jumping back in. I've been playing Apex, FEAR again and Trepang2 and now TF2 just feels clunky. There's a weird stickiness and lack of momentum. As long as you're wallrunning then things are fast, but the second you touch the ground you feel like a slug. Maybe that's what they wanted, but it feels slanted towards those who focus on grappling and mastering the momentum. Weapons also all feel pretty much the same and have too much grinding. Apex is superior in the ground movement, gunplay, and TTK. 

Anyways TF2 has a lot of "that was cool" moments, but nothing that is really too memorable. I can recall Half-Life's storyline, even the universe of Unreal Tournament. But Titanfall? It's such a mess of different settings and themes that don't mean anything nor say anything. Buy it, enjoy it, but I doubt it will be something you come back to excitedly and relive the same experience as your first.

This is how to make an excellent FPS. Solid shooting mechanics. Fast, free flowing movement with seamless transition from sliding to jumping, to wall running. A variety of Titans with awesome abilities like unleashing a barrage of missiles to feel like a boss, without ever feeling overpowered so the game is still challenging. The guns feel awesome, the characters don't just scream in your face for dramatic effect that gets annoying like CoD; they are just well acted with a sense of urgency for your mission. And the dialogue with your Titan has good humour mixed in too, it feels like you have a cool bond with it during the course of the campaign. Mission design is interesting too and has been well thought out to compliment your movement abilities with some really cool themes in some missions that think outside the box.

Only downside is I haven't been able to access the multiplayer servers but when I played this in the past it was excellent with lots of things to unlock with the different Titans, weapon skins etc so hopefully just a temporary issue. Was fun chaos with Pilots teaming up together to try take down players that had spawned their Titans.   

For the campaign alone this is still at least a 9/10. Great game.

As of my last knowledge update in January 2022, Titanfall 2 received widespread acclaim for its engaging gameplay, compelling story, and innovative mechanics. Developed by Respawn Entertainment and published by EA, Titanfall 2 is a first-person shooter that builds on the foundation laid by the original Titanfall. Here's a general overview of the game based on its reception:

Gameplay:

The core gameplay of Titanfall 2 revolves around the seamless integration of parkour-style movement for pilots and the powerful mechs called Titans.
The addition of a single-player campaign was well-received, featuring a captivating story with a strong emphasis on the bond between the protagonist, Jack Cooper, and his Titan, BT-7274.
The game introduces new Titan abilities, diverse pilot weaponry, and creative level design that encourages both strategic thinking and fast-paced action.
Story:

Titanfall 2's single-player campaign is often praised for its emotional depth, character development, and unexpected twists.
The dynamic between Jack and BT is a highlight, contributing to a unique narrative experience within the first-person shooter genre.
Multiplayer:

The multiplayer component retains the popular features of the original Titanfall, with enhanced customization options, new Titans, and maps.
The multiplayer mode is known for its fast-paced nature, verticality, and the interplay between on-foot and Titan gameplay.
Graphics and Sound:

Titanfall 2 boasts impressive graphics, with detailed environments and fluid animations.
The sound design, including the distinct sounds of Titans and weaponry, adds to the immersive experience.
Reception:

The game received critical acclaim for addressing the shortcomings of the first Titanfall, particularly the lack of a single-player campaign.
Reviewers praised the level design, inventive mechanics, and the seamless transition between on-foot and Titan gameplay.
Titanfall 2's Metacritic scores were consistently high across platforms.
Legacy:

While Titanfall 2 faced tough competition during its initial release, its reputation grew over time, and it developed a dedicated fan base.
The game's unique blend of storytelling, fluid movement, and intense multiplayer action has contributed to its status as a cult classic.
It's important to note that the gaming landscape may have evolved since my last update, and there could be additional developments or insights into Titanfall 2. If you're considering playing the game, checking more recent reviews and community feedback would provide the latest perspectives.

This is the best FPS on the market, and it's not even close. I've spent almost 20 years of my life playing a multitude of FPS games of every stripe, from 90's Build Engine games to the modern battle royal and extraction shooters; this is as peak as the genre has gotten so far.

The weapon sandbox, skill floor and skill ceiling, movement, feedback, and loadout customization here are beyond stellar. There's everything from the standard hitscan SMG's and AR's to a wacky twin-projectile sniper, a micro-missile machine gun, and a lightning rocket launcher. Loadouts allow for immense amounts of flexibility and creativity in how one plays, with grapple hooks and stim shots and wallhack throwing knives, cookable grenades and smoke bombs and satchel charges, and so much more. The movement is easy to pick up but has enough tech to leave a lot to learn and master even after 100 hours. Then there's the titular titans themselves, which all feel fantastic to use and each having entirely different styles of combat to learn and master. Not to even mention a well-crafted single player campaign that uses the sandbox to its fullest.

I cannot recommend this game enough, it goes on sale for less than $5 from time-to-time, and at that price even a single playthrough of the campaign is easily worth the price.

Titanfall 2 would be in the gamer’s hall of fame if there was one. The campaign is so good and it's been cheap for years.

If you're looking for a super long campaign or campaign that is going to tell a great profound story, Titanfalls campaign might fall short for you. Better to have a 7 hour campaign worth playing twice or even more, than a 10 hour one full of filler barely worth playing once though…

What the campaign will provide you with is a solid 6-8 hours of non-stop fun. Titanfall knows that it has a Micheal Bay action movie premise and commits to making it the best Micheal Bay action movie you will ever play.

The campaign has one massive strength with its story and that's how it develops the relationship between the character you play as and the Titan you pilot. The over-arching story is very much a cheesey Micheal Bay action movie plot but the story of Cooper(the player character) and BT is really something special.

This review is mainly for the campaign, not the multiplayer.
It's very short but sweet, and was more thoughtfully designed than I was expecting. Every mission is fairly long and stands out in its own way, whether that be the gameplay, the setting, the visuals, and everything works in tandem so well that it's hard to think of one working without the other.
I've never played Titanfall 1 and was never interested in this universe or its story, but this game still managed to have likeable characters that made the story enjoyable even when I didn't really understand what was actually happening most of the time.

Even with the servers back sometimes Northstar is just more reliable for finding servers and they have some pretty crazy custom stuff too which is enjoyable.
